item.title: A Private Blog Is Still a Blog
item.description:
I‚Äôve been wondering when the day would come after Scoble left Microsoft that I‚Äôd disagree with him enough to bring it up here.¬† There have been many days that I‚Äôve disagreed with him, but today is the day that I need to jump into the pool.¬†

Robert takes issue today with Live Spaces and how they call something a blog where the access is restricted.¬† It culminates in an entry today about What is a blog?.¬† He goes on to say how that he felt so strong about this that he put it in the book he ‚Äúco-authored‚Äù.

‚ÄúI feel so strongly about this stuff that we put this into our book as a common definition of why Blogging is hot. If your tool or service doesn‚Äôt comply with all five of these things it might be very cool (and there might be a LOT of them) but you shouldn‚Äôt be able to claim that they are blogs.‚Äù

Some pretty good comments in his post as well like this one from Eric Eggertson: __

‚ÄúBut, I wrote the book and we put that definition in there and no one argued with it when it became the best-selling blogging book. So, too late to argue the definition now.‚Äù

Ah, what a crazy world it would be if the act of publishing something made it true!

It‚Äôs never too late to argue about the definition. Otherwise, why would you have posted this to your ‚Äúblog‚Äù (if in fact it IS a blog)? If it was too late to argue about it, you wouldn‚Äôt have bothered.

Reading your disclaimer in the right margin, I see you don‚Äôt guarantee ‚Äúthe quality of the opinions or anything else offered here,‚Äù so I take that as an admission that you could be wrong. üòâ

And another by n00b:

‚ÄúI wrote the book and we put that definition in there and no one argued with it when it became the best-selling blogging book. So, too late to argue the definition now.‚Äù

WOW. You should tape yourself saying that and play it back over and over just to hear what an incredible ass you sound like.

Out of the hundreds of millions of people on the internet, how many do you think care about your book?

Why don‚Äôt you put up a poll somewhere and ask if things can be a blog if they don‚Äôt meet your royal highness‚Äôs 5 aspects? Right now it looks like not even any of your own readers agrees with you, I‚Äôd place money on you getting taken to the cleaners if this were ever put to a vote.

Seriously Robert, get over yourself already.¬†A blog that is private is still a blog. Sheesh..

item.title: Meet the EvNet Development Team
item.description:
[][1]

Charles sat down with our development team to learn more about The Evangelism Network codebase.  This is the code the team has been hard at work creating since the launch of [10][2]. We’ll ultimately have one set of code for both Channel 9 and 10.  We’ll also make sure we preserve the unique flair and personalities of each site. 

Jamie (long time Niner) sure seemed to like it¬†and even called the team heroes and wondered if evNet was for more than just 9. üôÇ

evNet is definitely more than just Channel 9.¬† It is also 10 üôÇ¬† Ok, sorry couldn‚Äôt resist.¬† The code will be used for other audience oriented media sites that our team ends up doing and hopefully tie them together as appropriate in one Network.¬†¬† (No big plans right now, but we‚Äôre thinking about the future.)

We‚Äôre being very, very careful and conservative though keeping expectations low.¬† We want to make sure we deliver on the promise of a great experinece for 9 and 10 first and then go on from that.¬† We are also still a very small team where everyone wears many hats (content development, mail room for c9 dolls, development, testing, design and site management).¬† I think that‚Äôs part of our sucess to date.¬† Lean and mean.

If you look at every single member of our team we all have our own individual blogs hosted on a wide variety of platforms (CS, Typepad, WordPress and Dasblog).¬†¬† I know from my perspective I‚Äôd love to move to something instead of Dasblog that runs on .NET.¬† CS is quite overkill for what I need and Dasblog is getting dated.¬†

Anyhow, thanks for the enthusiasm Jamie and everyone for what we‚Äôre doing with evNet.¬† I know it has probably felt in the past like we‚Äôve been paying way to much attention to 10 but it was¬†a purposeful plan to use a new greenfield to experiment with new ideas and build to start thje platform work with a new site, new audience and then move to 9.

Now it is time to take it to 9.

item.title: Making Friends When Travelling
item.description:
So, I‚Äôm back from my trip.¬† It was a trip of a life time.¬† We made so many new friends, learnt a lot more about students and saw some amazing use of technology.¬† Not just technology for technology sake mind you, stuff that really will change the world.¬† Charles on my team even wrote a poem about it.

One thing I am reminded of when travelling abroad¬†is how friendly we are when we run into someone we think is from our homeland.¬† One such example was when I was heading back home from Delhi and was waiting to go through Indian Immigration.¬†

A father with his family tapped me on the shoulder and said, ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre a long way from Canada‚Äù.¬†
I smiled and replied, ‚ÄúYes.¬† Great trip, looking forward to getting home.¬† How did you know I was from Canada?‚Äù
The Dad smiled back and replied, ‚ÄúYou have your Passport out, you have the same¬†type as we do.¬† We‚Äôre from Calgary, Alberta.‚Äù
I replied, ‚ÄúWow!¬† That‚Äôs where I went to college.‚Äù

As we waited for immigration to stamp our visas and exit India we started to chat about colleges in Calgary.¬† The daughter would be attending SAIT in the fall.¬† This was my college and when she found out she and she had all sorts of questions for me like, ‚ÄúWhat was the student residence like?‚Äù I joked about how if the walls could tell stories, it would be a best seller.¬†¬† Since my stay they‚Äôd built out several new residences then that were pretty state of the art and were self contained units with kitchens, bathrooms and a little living room.¬† Very different than the dorm experience you normally have.

We chatted a bit longer about our trips, how long we‚Äôd been away from home and eventually made it through to security and went our seperate ways.¬† We wished each other well, shook hands and said goodbye.

I‚Äôve seen and heard stories like this time and time again and you‚Äôll hear them say, ‚ÄúIt is a small world‚Äù.¬†

You know the world is really small and we‚Äôd probably have many more encounters like this if we‚Äôd just talk to each other.¬† We don‚Äôt reach out and talk to one another when travelling domestically.¬† When travelling domestically we always seem in a rush, a huff and puff when people are slow to get off of a plane or when there is a big line.¬†

Do we chat with people who are waiting in line at security?¬†

Nope.¬† That would be considered weird or intrusive.¬†

Pretty sad actually.

So today I would like to make a suggestion next time you have a short trip.¬† Heck, maybe try this even when you‚Äôre waiting in line at the bank.¬†üôÇ¬†¬† Reach out and chat with one person in a line and get to know them.¬†

Who knows you might run into an old lost friend, you might make a connection to your past or even better you might make a lonely person‚Äôs day.

Cheers!

technorati tags: Travelling+Abroad, Making+Friends

item.title: Update from Delhi
item.description:
So it has been almost 24 hours since my A little freaked out in Dehli post.¬† I was able to make alternative travel arrangements last night through corporate travel as there was a high probability that my flight out of Heathrow to Seattle could be cancelled on Sunday.¬† (The BBC news is reporting 40% of flights out of Heathrow right now are cancelled).¬† This does mean that I will be getting home about 24 hours sooner than planned, Saturday afternoon.

You know this is one of those amazing things about Microsoft.¬† The care for its people.¬† I sent an email last night to corporate travel, explaining my situation and looking for recommendations.¬† Within a short period of time I flight options available and was able to make a decision on which flight would work best.¬† The person on the other end was a human being and acted accordinly, not like a machine.¬† You could tell she was really working hard to get new flights for myself and others who were displaced due to the current events.¬† While this was all going on I was on the phone with my wife via Live Messenger call¬†as I worked through the details, giving her the latest.¬† Live Messenger has been amazing on this trip.¬† Charles and I both have been using it to keep up with family back home and as such I have only spent about $3.00 so far for my calls.¬† The ability to stay in touch with my family through the Internet has been a savior.¬†¬†

Obviously, I‚Äôm back at the hotel now with Charles and Laura.¬† We‚Äôre going to stay here at the hotel until it is time to go to the airport.¬† We‚Äôll do that in about 5 hours time.¬† There are warnings about terrorist attacks in India at the US Embassy today and over the weekend.¬† I will be happy to be on my way and am saying a prayer for all those travelling around the planet over the coming time ahead.¬† Our hotel has satelite televison so we are able to watch CNN and the BBC and able to keep up with lots of information on what is going on.

I am a little fuzzled, but I feel good about travelling right now.¬† Yeh, not great but I‚Äôll be fine.¬† I repacked my bags so all of my goods can fit in my check-in bag to make flying easier and am all ready to go.

India has been an amazing trip, a real eye opener in a number of ways.¬† The people are amazing, but I can say I‚Äôve never seen poverty like this.¬†¬†

_I can see a nation transforming itself.¬†
I see how the Internet and technology are helping democratize the world.
I see opportunities for many who did not have dreams only years ago.¬†
_
The students of Imagine Cup are amazing as well as are the breadth of their projects.¬† I‚Äôve seen WPF applications that were mind boggling, short films and minds hard at work to solve difficult computing challenges in record time.¬† All folks from the around the planet, all with one dream which is to revolutionize the health of our people with technology.¬†

No borders, just software.

So that is what‚Äôs happening right now. My bags are packed, I am relaxing watching the BBC and will be headed out to go home in a few hours.

In the past 24 hours I‚Äôve received countless emails from many wishing safe travels for all attending the Imagine Cup and prayers.¬†

Thank you.¬† It has been quite touching, I guess I‚Äôm going to have to quit saying only 7 people read this blog.

Home soon.¬† My thoughts and prayers are with all who are travelling.

item.title: A little freaked out in Delhi
item.description:
Ok, my wife is sleeping right now and I am sitting here in Delhi and what‚Äôs running through my mind is when my wife will hear the news about the terrorist plot being¬†thwarted in London.¬† Charles, Laura and I are watching the BBC news here in Delhi and are pretty freaked out.¬†

The way we understand it now is that certain American airlines like United, Continental and American were targetted by terrorists.¬† As of right now the measures being taken by authorities are that no carry on bags are allowed on flights and you are only allowed to bring on prescription medications and your travel documents.¬† Nothing else.¬† Good plan I say, whatever to make folks safe.¬† They have approximately 20 people in custody in London of British descent and the attacks were not necessarily for today, tonight, for the next few days but soon.¬† The authorities decided to step in and make the arrests.

I‚Äôm pretty shaken as I right this, not sure whether to call home now and wake my wife to let her know.¬† I know that if I do call her then she‚Äôll stay awake all night watching television and probably not have anymore information and just have to watch repeats of the information which is on hand.¬† So sweetie, I decided to let you sleep tonight as I am sure you won‚Äôt sleep well until I am home.

Sorry. üôÅ

We were trying figure out if we should try and re-route and take a different way home‚Ä¶¬† I think we‚Äôre probably best to stick with our plan in hand which is British Airways to London and then back home to Seattle.¬† I suspect that due to all the cancellations there will be much fewer flights and any changes could possibly result of getting bumped off of a flight home.¬† So many flights have been cancelled today it will take days for things to get back on track.

This sucks.¬†

So say a prayer for safe travels for all and of course sanity in an insane world.

Our evening will be interesting and a change of a pace from the afternoon of watching the BBC.¬† Tonight are the short film finals where all of the students watch the films created in entirety while in Agra and vote for the best.¬† I am definitely looking for the diversion.

Postscript: Lots of nice comments coming in via email and the comments in this post.¬† Thank you.

item.title: Calacanis on one hit wonders
item.description:
I think anyone who has completed a sucessful projects always wonder if their next one will meet the mark.¬† I remember when we were weeks away from launching Channel 9 Lenn Pryor and I were down in the parking garage of building 119 at Microsoft.¬† We were having a stress smoke and walking, wondering if we were actually creating something cool.¬† We wondered if our previous hits were our lasts.¬† I can relate a lot to this post.

Jason writes:

Someone transcribed a portion of the MCN (<‚Äìthat‚Äôs an MP3 file) Dave, Doc, and I did at Wikimania this week. Perhaps the best podcast we‚Äôve all done:

You tend to fall in love with your first brand, and you can‚Äôt let it go. And I did that with Silicon Alley Reporter magazine, and it‚Äôs well documented that I could have sold it for 20 million bucks, and I didn‚Äôt, and I got a fraction of that [when I eventually sold it], and then when the next [opportunity] came around, Weblogs, Inc., I sold it after 18 months, instead of holding the other brand [Silicon Alley Reporter] for six years, and I did much better in 18 months than I did in six years‚Ä¶

You have to always be confident that you are able to create another hit, you‚Äôre not a one-hit wonder, and that your future is always brighter than your past. You can‚Äôt live with this fear of losing this monster you created. And sometimes you gotta kill it, and I always give people the example of Bob Dylan, because when Bob Dylan took folk music as far as his interest in it‚Ä¶could go and then he said, ‚ÄúI want to do electric, it‚Äôs more interesting to me,‚Äù and there‚Äôs that famous thing at Royal Albert Hall where somebody yells at him and says, ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre Judas,‚Äù and [Dylan] says, ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt believe you, you‚Äôre a liiiiiiar,‚Äù [laughter] and then he turns around to his band and he says, ‚ÄúPlay real fuckin‚Äô louuuuuud,‚Äù and then he turns around and he plays ‚ÄúLike a Rolling Stone,‚Äù which is arguably his best song ever and he did some of his best work after that.

You have to reinvent yourself, and sometimes you have to kill your previous persona. I had to kill [my] Silicon Alley Reporter persona to become Weblogs, Inc. I‚Äôll have to kill Weblogs, Inc. to be Netscape, kill Netscape to be whatever comes after that. You can‚Äôt live on your past brand, or else it owns you, and you no longer own it.

This afternoon we went to the Taj Majal.¬† I can now say I‚Äôve been able to see at least one of the seven wonders of the modern world.¬† Charles went a long with me, but Laura unfortunately stayed behind as she is recovering herself today from the Delhi Belly.¬† Good news she was able to see the Taj Mahal yesterday when she was out with one of the Short Film category teams.

Here‚Äôs a picture of me in front of the Taj Mahal (this one is for you mom :-)) with many more in my Flickr gallery.¬†

So that‚Äôs it for today.¬†¬† I‚Äôm really enjoying myself, wondering what Delhi will be like but to be honest starting to look forward to finally getting home and driving

Programming Battle and Interface Design.¬† In each category the contestants compete 24/7 deciding when to sleep, eat and/or work.¬†

item.title: Live Clipboard: What, How and Why?
item.description:
Charles on our Channel 9 team sits down with Paresh Suthar and Matt Augustine to talk about the Live Clipboard.¬†

Don‚Äôt know what Live Clipboard is?¬† To get the meat check out Ray Ozzie‚Äôs original post entitled Wiring the Web.¬†

As Ray puts it‚Ä¶

The idea was based on using a simple and consistent user model to wire-the-web that would assist individuals in creating their own mesh of interconnections ‚Äì both web-to-web and web-to-PC.¬† Simply stated, we‚Äôd like to extend the clipboard user model to the web.¬†¬† So, where‚Äôs the clipboard of the web?

  • Where‚Äôs the user model that would enable a user to copy and paste structured information from one website to another?
  • Where‚Äôs the user model that would enable a user to copy and paste structured information from a website to an application running on a PC or other kind of device, or vice-versa?
  • ¬†And finally, where‚Äôs the user model that would enable a user to ‚Äúwire the web‚Äù, by enabling publish-and-subscribe scenarios web-to-web, or web-to-PC?

Watch and learn more on Channel 9.

item.title: How to live happily with a great designer
item.description:
Excellent Piece by Seth Godin.

  1. If you want average (mediocre) work, ask for it. Be really clear up front that you want something beyond reproach, that‚Äôs in the middle of the road, that will cause no controversy and will echo your competition. It‚Äôll save everyone a lot of time.
    • On the other hand, if you want great work, you‚Äôll need to embrace some simple facts:
      • It‚Äôs going to offend someone. If it doesn‚Äôt offend them, then it will make them nervous. The Vietnam Vets memorial offended a lot of people. The design of Google made plenty of people nervous. Great work from a design team means new work, refreshing and remarkable and bit scary.
        • It‚Äôs not going to be easy to sell to your boss. That‚Äôs your job, by the way, not mine. If you want me to do something great, you‚Äôve got to be prepared to protect it and defend it. Come back too many times for one little compromise, and you‚Äôll make it clear that #1 was what you wanted all along.
          • You can‚Äôt tell me you‚Äôll know it when you see it. First, you won‚Äôt. Second, it wastes too much time. Instead, you‚Äôll need to have the patience to invest twenty minutes in accurately describing the strategy. That means you need to be abstract (what is this work trying to accomplish) resistant to pleasing everyone (it needs to do this, this and that) and willing, if the work meets your strategic goal, to embrace it even if it‚Äôs not to your taste.
            • Help me out by pointing out the work you‚Äôd like this to be on a peer with. If you want a website to be like three others (in tone, not in execution) then point it out. In advance.
              • Be clear about dates and costs. Not what you hope for, but what you can live with!
                • You don‚Äôt know a lot about accounting so you don‚Äôt backseat drive your accountant. You hired a great designer, please don‚Äôt backseat drive here, either.
                  • If you want to be part of the process, please go to school. Read design magazines or take a course from Milton Glaser or get a subscription to Before & After. By the way, that one link is the single best part of this post.
                    • This one may surprise you: don‚Äôt change your existing design so often. Not when your kids or your colleagues tell you it‚Äôs time. Do it when your accountant says so.
                      • Don‚Äôt get stressed about your logo.
                        • Get very stressed about user interface and product design. And your packaging.
                          • Say thank you. technorati tags: Designers

item.title: When you have a bad day ‚Äî make it your own‚Ä¶
item.description:
For the last 20 years July 27th has been a very sad day.¬† You see July 27th is the anniversary of when my only brother died.¬†¬† Rod was 21 years old and was killed in a head on collision while driving home to Estevan, Saskatchewan fro Regina.¬† This year marks the 20th anniversary.

It happened during a really bad rainstorm when a truck hydroplaned, lost control and drove head on into his car. Rod died instantly.¬† Man, his wedding day was only a month away.¬† He left behind a fiancee, countless friends, a little brother and a Mom and Dad.¬† He had just completed Electronics Engineering and had a whole life ahead of him.

My brother and I shared one passion and a dream‚Ä¶.¬† That dream was to own a Corvette.

Ever since Rod and I were the yougest of age we talked about Corvettes, drew pictures of Corvettes, built Lego Corvettes, bought plastic models of Corvettes and imagined our bicycles were Corvettes.¬† We‚Äôd beg Dad to take us down to the Chevrolet dealership when the new models came in and just look at them, returning home with a brochure as a treasure.¬† Never actually thinking we‚Äôd ever own one.

20 years ago on July 27th, a police officer pulled up to our home in Estevan to inform us that Rod had died in a car accident.¬† I remember seeing my mom and dad almost collapse at the news, what a blow.¬† Shock, disbelief not sure what else to say.¬† I can remember the numbness, like someone kicking you right in the stomach.¬†¬† I‚Äôll always remember the funeral people from around the country and that Rod‚Äôs gravestone has a Corvette emblem on it.¬† The emblem served as a reminder for something he did not have time with us to purchase.

So July 27th has always been a bad day.

Each year as it comes around my family is sad, we remember how hard it was to push through emotions, the tears, the sadness and the funeral.¬† My family puts a tribute in the classifieds of the local paper to also mark the day.

So I decided this year to take July 27th back for me.¬† No more sadness, no more tears, let‚Äôs get a great memory to happen on this day.

Yesterday I found a Corvette, my first one and bought it.¬† It is like new, is in impeccable condition with only 12,000 miles and is a dream come true.

So when I had locked on a price and the deal was final, I called Dad and told him what I bought.¬† We were both so excited, running through features, model and year.¬† I then said, ‚ÄúDad, Rod would be proud.‚Äù¬† silence came over the phone‚Ä¶ We both broke down over the phone in tears and choked up, we both could not talk.

I then returned to the sales office where my wife was to finish the deal and replayed the story back for her and the sales manager.¬† We all actually teared up a bit again.

So I drove home a happy person and now have a new memory for July 27th.¬† A very good one.

Enjoy life, hug your family and go after your dreams‚Ä¶

When you have anniversaries for moments that are sad, take them back and make them good ones‚Ä¶

We‚Äôre only here for a short time‚Ä¶

¬†

item.title: Stand ‚Äì Rascall Flatts ‚Äì The Jeff Sandquist Theme Song
item.description:
You know my wife teases me often that I am more Texan than her. :->¬† I grew up in the small prairie town of Estevan, Saskatchewan, Canada.¬† Where the primary industries are oil, farming and ranching.¬† Sounds a little like Texas to me.¬†No wonder I married a girl¬†from Dallas.¬†

So it shouldn‚Äôt surprise you that I love good country music.¬† My favorite artist of all time has got to be Rascal Flatts.¬† It is the first artist I copy over to my media library on a new laptop or device and my wife and kids are so sick of Fast Cars and Freedom I think they are now hiding that CD.¬† Their song ‚ÄúStand‚Äù will most likely go down as the Jeff Sandquist theme song, you have just got to love the chorus, it goes something like this:

_‚ÄòCause when push comes to shove
You taste what you‚Äôre made of
You might bend ‚Äòtil you break
‚ÄòCause it‚Äôs all you can take
On your knees you look up
Decide you‚Äôve had enough
You get mad, you get strong
Wipe your hands, shake it off
Then you stand, then you stand

Every time you get up and get back in the race
One more small piece of you starts to fall into place ‚Äì yeah

Listen here

One of the interesting things about living life with a blog like this is that people get to see when things are going amazingly well.¬†¬† You also see the bumps along the way too.¬† So lately with everything that‚Äôs been going on quite a few folks have asked how I‚Äôm doing.¬† üòâ

Tonight I returned home from being away from my wife and daughters for about a week and half.¬† I was able to take in a slight detour and visit Mom and Dad in Estevan.¬†¬† What a treat.¬†¬†I needed the break as while all the drama with Robert and Vic my team was finishing up Version 1.0 of 10 as well as launching several new programs for our field that will see us taking Evangelism to new levels this coming year.¬†¬†¬† To be honest, it wasn‚Äôt until I got back to Estevan that I was able to unplug and reflect up on everything that‚Äôs been going on.

So how am I doing?¬†¬†

Well, after some crazy hard weeks I am now standing, ready to take on a big year at home and at Microsoft. üôÇ¬†

So happy I went to MGX this year, but oh so happy to be finally back home with my family.¬†

item.title: Northwest Airlines is late
item.description:
Ok, very interesting day today in watching customer service in action.  If you know me, I’m a glass is half full kind of guy. Not today.

Today, I am returning from Orlando and making my way up to Minot, North Dakota.  My parents live in Estevan, Saskatchewan which is about two hours north of that.  The Canadian Sandquists are having a family reunion tonight with folks coming from all around the country.  I’ve been pretty excited about it, but hadn’t had much time to think about it all as I’ve been heads down preparing for [MGX][1] and the [10 1.0 Ship][2].  So needless to say once I had MGX behind me and I started to think about the prospects of seeing folks I haven’t seen for years tonight, I got really excited.

This morning I got on the plane in Orlando that was going to get me to Minneapolis.  From there I take short flight off to Minot, North Dakota where my Dad would pick me up to drive the rest of the way to Estevan.  Estevan is a small town of about 10,000 people and the airport doesn’t have commercial flights.

So I’m on board the flight and the captain comes over the speaker to say that we’d be delayed for about 10 minutes.  I figure no sweat, I’ve got an hour and half stop in Minneapolis, I’m fine.  The pilot comes on again to say maybe 10 minutes longer.  I’m a little nervous now as I know the flight schedules off by heart to Minot from Minneapolis.  There’s an early morning flight, one in the afternoon (the one I am scheduled for) and a 10:30 pm flight.  I figure I should mention this to one of the flight attendants so I can see how long they are really thinking it will take.

One thing that drives me insane is when people are rude to the flight attendants when there are delays.  I’m pretty sure its not their fault and when there are mechanical problems they aren’t in control of the mechanics.  Heck, that is what unions are for. :->  So when I talk to the attendant and explain that I really need to get on the afternoon flight Minot out of Minneapolis as I have family reunion it bothers me a bit when she rudely tells me to “call the 1-800” number and walks away. 

The rancher from North Dakota sitting next me jokes, “Hey I thought they only did that when you were an ass to them”. I waited a bit longer as the captain came over the speaker to say just 10 more minutes.  I decided to stand up to make my call to the 1-800 and stretch my legs at the same time.  I notice that most of the first class cabin was cleared out and they no have the door open to the gate.

I find out they sent a number of folks on First Class to another gate to Minneapolis.  I grab my bags to see if I can get on that plane (my wife calls me a luckbox as things usually work out my way), but not today.  Its full.  (with the first class passengers from my original flight).   There is no way I am going to make my afternoon flight to Minot.  The Northwest attendant books me onto the 10:30 pm flight to Minot, I call my folks to give them the bad news.  Their bummed, a few of my cousins fly out in the morning, so I won’t see them.  The attendant apologizes again and says, “Man.  We screwed up”.  She also could not print me a boarding pass as there was more than 6 hours until my flight out of Minneapolis. 

I get into Minneapolis and try and get a boarding pass for my flight to Minot and the attendant at the desk couldn’t find me one.  He finally grumbles, “Look can you just go the main ticketing desk in the main terminal?  You have plenty of time!”  I decide to go for walk and find the supervisor to respectfully vent about my day and see if I can get a boarding pass from him without having to make the trek in and out of security.

After about 30 minutes, I finally tracked down a supervisor and had a great discussion about the day.¬† He was apologetic and said , ‚ÄúSir, since we declared bankruptcy the flight attendance and staff really just don‚Äôt care for the passengers anymore.¬† I know they should, but they don‚Äôt‚Äù.¬† He did bump me up to first class, apologized profusely and I made my way to find a wifi connection where I could plug-in and charge my laptop.¬† I tried to see if I could get a first class lounge pass and he said we only do that for international delays.¬†¬†

It is kind of poetic justice I guess that Channel 9, is modelled after the transparency found by United Airlines.¬†¬† Today my experience by Northwest was not transparent.¬† If they had been transparent I could have gotten on a different airline and made my way to the family reunion.¬† So that‚Äôs been my day.¬† It is not the end of the world, I think a few of the folks who are attending the reunion will be going for brunch tomorrow and I‚Äôll have less of a hangover tomorrow too.

I did make one amazing discovery at the Minneapolis Airport.¬† I found a

sweet location to plug-in your laptop and get on the airport.¬† The TGI Fridays in terminal C has a long table of stools with ample plug ins.¬†¬† The food is ok and I can relax here for the next¬†4 hours while I wait for my flight.¬†

It is always hard to find a good power source at airports, so while sitting here I started up a Wiki to begin tracking power sources and Wi-Fi locations at airports across the globe.¬† (I‚Äôll fine tune it a bit more later).¬† Hopefully this can become something as cool as my Getting Things Done Toolkit Wiki.

More later‚Ä¶¬†¬† Off to eat a ‚Äústeak‚Äù at TGI Fridays with a plastic knife.

Postscript:¬† My favorite post about airlines is this one by Rick Segal.¬† With my Treo I had faster information to flights than the flight attendants or the gateworkers.¬† Kayak.com _was actually giving me the number of available seats on the flights.

If you are in the Minneapolis airport pop on over to TGI Friday‚Äôs we‚Äôre having a blogger meetup in terminal C.

Post-Post (bored at the airport) script:¬† I decided a Flickr photogroup for tracking power outlets _is a better idea.

item.title: Microsoft 10 Version 1.0 is now online
item.description:
After a late night and a team in two different time zones (I‚Äôm in Orlando, Florida attending an internal conference) we shipped a major update to 10.¬†

Links:

  • Me on 10 ‚Äì Welcome to 10 Version 1.0
  • Jesse ‚Äì 7 Day Software, featuring Newsgator
  • Scoble ‚Äì Up Early to Watch the 10 launch
  • Tina ‚Äì San Diego to Alaska with a blog, a camera and two wheels
  • Michael Gannotti ‚Äì Is 10 a 10

We did learn a lot on our way to this release.¬† One consistent piece of feedback you gave us was that 10 lacked a purpose and the major side effect was that our content often was all over the map.

As a team we really took that to heart and wrote what the 10 Manifesto. This manifesto is a set of principles we‚Äôll use as a compass to help guide us forward.

The 10 Manifesto

  • One band of passionate digital citizens reaching out to enthusiasts around the globe.
    • Two-way communication that is based on mutual respect will lead to success.
      • Three degrees make up the interview: The medium, the subject, and the conversation.
        • Four corners of the world encompass millions of ideas and a shared global imagination.
          • Five by five is how we communicate; with maximum strength and clarity.
            • Six minutes of headlines and links isn‚Äôt enough. We want to create opinions, depth, and focus.
              • Seven days a week we hunt for discussions on seven continents. Work and life can be synthesized

                • Eight bits of media will grow into more than just bytes of data. They should inform and enthrall.

                  • Nine plus Ten is much more than nineteen. Together we can teach, listen, and learn together.
                  10 is all of these things, but most important it is what our users make it. Listen to everyone.

                The technology behind the site is the stuff folks saw at MIX, ASP.NET 2.0, Atlas, SQL 2005.¬† Heck we even did a lot of our UI work using Expression Web Designer.¬† The site was written from the ground up starting last February and we‚Äôve been iterating since then.¬† Its a complete end to end blogging solution as well as forums that treats media as a first class citizen.¬† I am in complete awe at how quickly this is coming together.¬† Ultimately this will be the code-base that Channel 9 will move towards in September (we‚Äôll obviously preserve the tone and flair that is unique to C9) but having one codebase for all the properties in what we call the Evangelism Network will be helpful to us.¬† We‚Äôll roll in a Wiki soon and have a few other surprises up our sleeve that we‚Äôll disclose soon.

                We have more work to do on this, the team is fixing the inevitable launch bugs, but I definitely feel like we‚Äôre on our way with Channels 9 and 10.

item.title: The 10 Commandments of Email
item.description:
[][1]

Along with the 5 Temptations of a CEO, the 10 Commandments of Email is another great read.¬†

  1. Don‚Äôt use your in-box as a catchall folder for everything you need to work on. Read items once, and answer them immediately if necessary, delete them if possible, or move them to project-specific folders.
    • Set up a ‚ÄúFive Weeks Folder‚Äù that deletes its content automatically after five weeks. Use it as a repository for messages you‚Äôre unsure about, such as that email you want to delete, but you‚Äôre not sure if the guy‚Äôs going to call you tomorrow and ask about it.
      • Assist colleagues‚Äô inbox-filtering efforts by agreeing on acronyms to use in subject lines that quickly identify action items and other important messages. Sample acronyms: < AR> , Action Required; < MSR>, Monthly Status Report.
        • Send group mail only when it is useful to all recipients. Use ‚Äúreply-to-all‚Äù and ‚ÄúCC:‚Äù buttons sparingly.
          • Ask to be removed from distribution lists that you don‚Äôt need to be on.
            • To cut down on pileup, use the ‚Äúout-of-office‚Äù feature of your email, in addition to your voice mail, to notify people when you are traveling.
              • When possible, send a message that is only a subject line, so recipients don‚Äôt have to open the email to read a single line. End the subject line with < EOM>, the acronym for End of Message.
                • Graphics and attachments are fun, but they slow down your ability to download messages when you‚Äôre on the road. Use them sparingly.

                  • If you‚Äôre sending an attachment larger than 5 MB to a large group of recipients, consider putting it on the company‚Äôs Web site or intranet instead.

                    • Be specific. If you send a 20-page attachment, tell the recipient that the important information is on pages 2 and 17.
Nice.

item.title: Communities are Music Festivals
item.description:
People throw the ‚Äúcommunity‚Äù word around a lot at Microsoft and throughout the industry.¬† To be honest it is not one of my most favorite words or phrases even though my team‚Äôs mission is creating places like Channel 9 and 10.

I like to think of the end goal for sites like Channel 9 and 10 is to have something that resembles a music festival.¬† If you attend a music festival like Bumbershoot¬†or Farm Aid¬†what you notice right away is that often the most interesting aspects of the event aren‚Äôt always happening on mainstage.¬† The people who are attending and the things they do often are more interesting than the performers on stage.¬† From the folks selling food, people juggling or the children getting their faces painted.¬†

With Channel 9 and 10 this is what we aspire to create.¬† We dream of a day where the participation by our members either rivals our outshines the content that‚Äôs happening on the mainstage.

It takes a long time to get there but if I look at things like Channel 9 park, Minh‚Äôs recent Brokeback Redmond video¬†and the depth of content on the Channel 9 wiki¬†it makes¬†me believe that this is a reasonable¬†dream.¬†¬†We will ship this week what we‚Äôre calling 10 Version 1.0¬†which our hope is that 10 V1.0 is a baby step for creating a place that enthusiasts will cherish as much as the Niners do Channel 9.

item.title: Creating a Log file with Windows Notepad
item.description:
Disclaimer: I saw this on DIGG _the other day, but can‚Äôt find it via search this morning to attribute.¬†
_
I am a Windows Notepad user, I use it throughout the day to keep running notes from meetings that I later consolidate into meeting notes and actions.¬† It works well.¬† I should probably use OneNote or something but I like the simplicity of a basic text editor like notepad.¬†¬†¬†

So here‚Äôs one cool little trick for notepad that allows you to to automatically keep a simple date/time stamp in notepad as you open/add to a log.

  • Start Notepad.

  • On the top line of the file type: .LOG (must be capitalized) ,  save the file with any name

  • Re-open it

  • A date/time stamp is added to the file below the word .LOG — add some text below that.

  • _Save and_ reopen again a new date/time stamp is  listed below the text.

    • It will look like this:

    .LOG
    9:46 AM 7/9/2006
    HELLO
    9:46 AM 7/9/2006
    HELLO Again

    It is teresting that this is hidden in notepad, I wonder what else is in their?¬† Tim Sneath told me the other day that if I use Notepad so much that I should give Notepad2 a whirl.¬† Omar also has instructions on replacing Notepad with Notepad2.¬† I do need to give that¬†a whirl.

item.title: Sharepoint Version 3.0 Multiple File Upload Wizard
item.description:
I love Sharepoint Version 3.0.¬† Its really a big improvement over the previous versions in many ways.¬† What do they say?¬† V3 is where we get it right? üôÇ

So tonight, I‚Äôm working on slides tonight for a talk that Joe Wilson and Christian Frei are delivering at the end of July.¬† So that my Friday night is not a complete bust, I am working on the deck from the lobby of my hotel, enjoying a cocktail, using the free wi-fi in the lobby and doing some people watching.

The slides have a lot of graphics and a couple of embedded videos so its huge.¬† When I did attempt to upload the deck, my connection would time out before the upload would complete.¬† I really needed to get the latest updates online so to lock on the outline.¬† Just as I was about to go and find a wired connection, I noticed an upload multiple files option below the standard upload item.¬†

I selected it and was taken to a page where I could easily select items from my local PC.¬†¬† I selected my slides this time when went to upload the slides, SharePoint used BITS to transfer the slides (BITS stands for background intelligent transfer) which works very well at uploading and downloading files over slow connections without timing out.

This is the upload dialog.¬† BITS is the same mechanism Windows Update uses to send critical updates to your local machine and its available for any developer to incorporate into their application.¬† In fact Duncan on my team wrote a .NET wrapper for BITS quite sometime ago.

This is sweet.¬† SharePoint V3 I love you‚Ä¶¬†¬† Slides uploaded, time for another cocktail. üôÇ

item.title: The Five Temptations of a CEO
item.description:
So last night at the recommendation of Jeff Erwin I picked up some of Patrick Lencioni‚Äôs books. I blazed through the Five Temptations of a CEO, it is a very quick read that you can easily get through in one sitting.¬†

Really good, common sense advice.¬†¬†The book is written as a short story that reminded me of David Chilton‚Äôs Wealthy Barber series.

**The 5 Temptations of a CEO
**

  1. Choosing status over results
    Is it a personal failure for you if your organization fails?¬† It better be.¬† Will you put your career on the line for the team, for the project or is your status and fame more important?

  2. Choosing popularity over accountability
    Avoiding using your directs as a venting ground, I guess this is why some folks say its lonely at the top. There‚Äôs a lot to this one.

  3. Choosing certainty over clarity
    I call this being afraid to make a decision or overanalyzing situation.¬† Time and time again I‚Äôve seen quick decisions that are correct and long thought out decisions to be wrong or validating what your gut feeling was.

  4. Choosing harmony over productive conflict
    Often the most productive meetings can be heated.¬† Respectful conflict without personal attacks is fine and often the most productive in meetings. Are your meetings Switzerland and consensus driven? I hope not.

  5. Choosing invulnerability over trust
    Admitting that you were wrong is a key trait of a strong leader. Make decisions intelligently and quickly. When you wrong were be up front and transparent about it.

I wrote them out here so I can commit them to memory.¬† Just reading them here though does not do them justice.¬† Thanks Jeff for the recommendation. I do need to read this book again, but¬†I will do that though after I finish The Four Obsessions of an Extraordinary Executive.

Postscript: Edited to include more of my own opinions in italics‚Ä¶

item.title: Practicing Leadership with Patrick M. Lencioni
item.description:
Some really good coments over on Scoble‚Äôs post about leadership.¬† I‚Äôve never been a big fan of the term management, I prefer leadership.¬† Managers have subordinates, leaders have followers. In one of the comments Jeff Erwin recommends Patrick M. Lencioni‚Äôs books on leadership.¬†

He writes:

‚ÄúMy best advice is to go purchase all five books written by Patrick M. Lencioni and read them each twice. This will take you about one day to do, they are fast reads and very interesting.

_Follow the books to the letter.‚Äù

  1. Listen, do not pontificate. You are not necessarily the smartest person in the room.

  2. Remember that when you render your opinion in a meeting as the ‚Äòmanager‚Äô, you are dictating. This will lead to many wrong decisions as your team blindly follows in an attempt to make you happy.

  3. Learn to ask questions, not render opinions.

Awesome advice.

Robert has said some pretty kind things about me lately on his blog, I‚Äôm not sure if they are all deserved üôÇ but they are nice to hear.¬† To be truthful, I still have plenty to learn about leading team even though I‚Äôve been doing it for quite sometime.¬†

I like to think of it as practicing leadership though as opposed to being a leader.¬† Similar to how a physicians say they practice medicine leaders practice leadership. The climate, conditions, people and environment are constantly changing. So leaders need to be continuously learning and changing themselves.

I‚Äôll be picking up Lencioni‚Äôs library next time I‚Äôm at Borders.¬† Thanks Jeff.

I‚Äôll be honest I really wondered how useful a device like this would be.¬† You see I always have a laptop open in my kitchen or in our family room.¬† I‚Äôm an email/blog addict, just part of the lifestyle I guess.¬† It drives my wife nuts, my obsession in always having a PC around just to skim through blogs and mail to see what‚Äôs going on..

The Origami is small.¬† It takes up little space on an end table and even better by installing the Flickr screensaver¬†and propping it up on its built-in stand when the device is not in use it displays recent additions to our family photo pool¬†on Flickr.¬† Its much more than just a digital picture frame, its a full functioning PC!¬† So when I want to check mail, I can just pick the device up and use Outlook.¬† No laptop taking up space on the kitchen counter or¬†on our coffee table.¬† If you are going to do this, you do need to change your power management features so that the monitor is not turned off after 10 minutes of inactivity when plugged in.¬† Otherwise you won‚Äôt have more than 10 minutes of photos. üôÇ

item.title: Vic Gundotra Leaves Microsoft for Google
item.description:
__Yes, its true, Vic Gundotra is leaving Microsoft for Google.

Unless you have been on vacation in some remote location I‚Äôm sure you have already read the news that Vic has decided to make the move to Google after 15 years at Microsoft.

I‚Äôve worked for Vic pretty much my entire career at Microsoft. Through it all he has been an inspiration to me and¬†my teams and also someone who I look up to. So to be honest, I‚Äôve struggled with what to write here.¬†

Its pretty simple though‚Ä¶

  1. Yes, it sucks.
  2. Yes, Vic is an amazing hire for Google.
  3. Yes, Microsoft will survive.¬†

In fact we‚Äôll grow and trust me when I say our best is yet to come. You see one of the many things Vic taught me is that during what can seem like the hardest times is when teams pull together to do their finest work.¬† This will happen even in his absence.¬† Right now I‚Äôm seeing my teams at their all time best.

There are lots of blogs talking about Vic leaving.¬† Mini¬†, Scoble¬†, Niall¬†, and Dave¬†all give their two cents.¬† Even more can found on Technorati.¬† Of course though they miss the fact that their is a human side to all of this and that is what I am trying to get across here. Vic leaves behind friends, a company which he helped build and a team of folks who look up to him.¬†My wife did sort of allude to that in one of her recent posts¬†talking about how interesting this month has been.¬† Month?¬† How about years üôÇ

The good news is Vic built a strong team at Microsoft ready to take the charge forward for Evangelism.¬† So yes, its been a hard week, but life will go on.

Vic, I know you‚Äôll just love this photo üôÇ (inside joke ‚Äî Vic always told me he hated this one) but I couldn‚Äôt find anything in the Windows Live image search¬†or even Google¬†for Gundotra.

Enjoy the year off Vic‚Ä¶.

Postscript:¬† Added a link to Scoble‚Äôs where was Google¬†post which is making its rounds on TechMeme.

item.title: Skateboarding Again
item.description:
So if you‚Äôre following along on my wife‚Äôs blog you‚Äôll already know that I‚Äôve gotten back into skateboarding:

Jeff got his skateboard this past Monday (I have some pics of him and Josie using it that he will have to put up later ..) and it took about 24 hours and she decided she just had to get one too. So, last night we took everyone to Redmond Town Center, including Brady The Dog, and walked around. When we got to Zumiez, Brady walked right on in, like he‚Äôd been there millions of times before (he hasnt ever been there) and wagged his tail for everyone, then decided it was cooler outside on the walkway.. and went to lay down and wait for us.¬†

Emily, a very nice young lady who made Jeff‚Äôs board, had all of Josie‚Äôs choices laid out for her when we got there. Oh, big kudos to Emily for saving everyone a lot of time. Josie chose which picture she wanted on the bottom of her board then picked a set of blue wheels with a pink stripe in the middle.

That‚Äôs ‚ÄúWet Willy‚Äù on the bottom of her board. It really holds no significance other than she thought he was funny. Jeff scooped up a bunch of pink decals for the new black helmut. So far, only a small we willy sticker is on it.. I assume she will have it covered in pink in no time, so the black is all blotted out.¬†

No I have not lost my mind.¬† Seriously. üôÇ

Last two weeks each evening Josie and I have been grabbing our boards, heading down to the neighborhood basketball court and practicing.¬† She‚Äôs really picking it up quick and just loves it.¬† For me, its a really great way to unplug from the day and spend sometime with Josie with zero interruptions.¬† Yes, I‚Äôve certainly gotten some insane looks lately from folks wondering if I‚Äôm off my rocker teaching a six year old to skate, but I‚Äôm hoping it is in here genes to skate.¬† I was able to scan a few photos in tonight from when I was her age, back in the mid 70s that I blogged about earlier on¬†about the retro G&S boards.

That‚Äôs me at the Mountain Mania Halfpipe in Kamloops, B.C.¬†

That‚Äôs me doing a hand stand while waiting for the half pipe to free up.¬† You‚Äôll notice in true Canadian form I‚Äôm wearing a hockey Jersey, hockey elbow pads and a hockey helmet.¬† Lots of good memories from back then and its also amazing exercise.

So how am I getting back into boarding?¬†

Slowly ‚Äî In Josie‚Äôs eyes I‚Äôm star that can do lots of tricks, in reality I‚Äôm starting all over again and she‚Äôs not that far behind me skill wise.¬† We‚Äôre spending most of our time at the local basketball court practicing ground moves.¬† I‚Äôve found a couple of free resources though with lots of good information on skateboarding.¬† About.com has a great section on skateboarding¬†with tips on how to ollie and even buying your first board.¬† The next was a complete surprise which is Comcast On Demand.¬† If you go to On Demand -> Sports and Fitness -> SportSkool -> Skateboarding you can find all sorts of video tutorials on basic ground moves and more advanced stuff.¬† If you don‚Äôt have Comcast, you can view it all online too at SportSkool.com.

So my new board has become basic transportation inside the house (Did I tell you wife is cool and how much I love hardwood floors!) I‚Äôm starting to feel like my balance is back and I can even do a 360.¬† The goal I‚Äôm working towards is to actually get to the park at lunch time as there are a number of folks who go each day.¬† It might take a bit, but I‚Äôll get there and through the process get more quality time with Josie.¬†

So far so good. :->¬† So¬†if you‚Äôre¬†thinking of taking the dive back to boarding and are in the Redmond area, drop me a line.¬† This coming weekend Josie and I are going to scout the Redmond park.

item.title: Best Wishes to my friend Robert Scoble
item.description:
A little over three years ago Robert became a close member of my family. Since then I consider myself one of the lucky to be able to work so closely with him and to watch him grow.¬† Inch by inch he has grown from blogger to one of the voices of transparency for our company.¬† There‚Äôs a lot of coverage out on the net about Robert‚Äôs new adventure, but I think Marc Orchant covered it best in his post¬†by referencing Henry Wadsworth Longfellow‚Äôs A Psalm of Life_._

Lives of great men all remind us
¬†We can make our lives sublime,
And departing, leave behind us
¬†Footprints on the sands of time.

Very few people get to be a part of the creation something magical like Robert and¬†I.¬† Robert has definitely left his footprints on my team and our company.¬† I still remember the day Lenn and I handed Robert and Charles cameras and asking them to interview people inside Microsoft.¬† Who would have know we‚Äôd be where are today and the rest as they say is history.¬†

So as I reflect on today, I‚Äôm sad to see Robert move on, but deep down as a Dad I‚Äôm happy that he‚Äôll be able to spend more time with Patrick and his family in the valley.

item.title: Channel 9 Update Planning
item.description:
I made the following post over in the Channel 9 Coffehouse this morning.

We‚Äôre in the process of planning out our next major update to Channel 9.¬† We‚Äôre starting this with this post thread here in the Coffeehouse.

As many of you have noticed we‚Äôve been doing a fair amount of work building out the recently launched 10¬†site.¬†We have another update planned¬†for 10 that should launch in the next couple of weeks.¬† When that update is complete we plan to move back onto Channel 9.

Long time Niners know that Channel 9 is built on a mutation of the ASP.NET Forums (the predecessor to community server) and it has become difficult to update.¬† With the launch of 10 we set off to build a new codebase that we could grow into for all of the sites that our team is asked to create.¬† With 10, bit by bit we‚Äôre getting the base infrastructure required for Channel 9.¬† In fact if¬†you look closely at the site, you‚Äôll notice the recent additions of a media library and soon there will be forums.

Our dream is to have one code base across our sites, but preserve the tone, style and integrity that is 9.¬†

Our curent thinking is to do two updates to Channel 9.¬† The first would include a homepage redesign to simplify and also to improve visibility to the large amount of content being created on Channel 9.¬† In this release we‚Äôll also perform a number of bug fixes and minor feature updates.¬† These will be completed in the short term and our hope is have it released somewhere around the end of June.

Once this is complete we‚Äôll move onto a bigger project that will get 9 running on the same ‚Äúcore base‚Äù as 10.¬†We promise never to take away from the soul of Channel 9.¬† We are deeply aware that the sites have different audiences :-), but we do need to get on one codebase for the sites.¬† Some things will only be present in C9 and others will get shared across the site.¬† For example we want to update Sandbox and revamp the Wiki this year, most likely those features won‚Äôt get pushed over to 10.

We‚Äôll use this thread to keep you up to date, share screenshots of the hompage redesign and include further updates on the C9 V3 project.

Let us know what you think.¬† Niners made C9 what it is, we need your help to make it better.
¬†

We need your help to make this update great. Hard to believe its been over two years since Channel 9 launched¬†what a ride, but we‚Äôre just getting started. üôÇ

item.title: G&S Fiebreflex Old School Boards
item.description:
I started skateboarding when I was six years old.¬† This was when I was also riding BMX freestyle and riding motocross.¬† I‚Äôve always wanted to live my life a little on the edge.¬† Now that I have kids and think about my passions from the past, I wonder how my parents slept at night, wondering if a trip to the ER was on the agenda for the next day.¬†

This morning Josie and I were digging through old photo albums to see if I could show her a photo of her dad doing handstands or a 360 on a half pipe when I was six.¬† We came up empty handed, but I‚Äôm still looking.

I had the coolest babysitter back in the 70s.¬†His name was Mitchell Erickson.¬† When ‚ÄúMitch‚Äù was sixteen he took me along with his friends and taught me to skateboard.¬† How many 16 year olds want a 6 year old tagging along?¬† Mitch didn‚Äôt mind, although now that I think about it maybe I was ‚Äúbait‚Äù for the skateboarding girls?¬† There always were girls around.¬† üôÇ¬† We reallly had¬†a great group of skaters in our pack.¬† In fact one the older kids¬†in our pack was Canadian champion and went on to the participate in the world skateboarding championships of 1976.¬† If you‚Äôve seen the movie Lords of Dogtown¬†this event was actually shown near the end of the movie. These were fun times and I can clearly remember hanging out at the skateboard shop, watching tricks and of course attempting my own.

In the last couple of years I‚Äôve had a couple of failed attempts to get back into skating but have resolve to get back into the sport.¬† My recent discovery of an old school skateboarders¬†club at Microsoft has got me looking around for a board again with even greater resolve.¬†

My first board was a Fibreflex bowl rider, I found the original advertisement on the web for it and have placed it to the right of this post.¬† Turns out G&S has recently reissued¬†their skateboards from the 70s and has got me thinking about picking up as a souvenir.¬† There is even a Stacy Peralta limited edition (only 300 made).¬† I can still remember the first ad I saw of the G&S boards in skateboarder magazine¬†and wanting one in the worst way.¬† My brother and I used to fight over our¬†subscription copy of that magazine whenever arrived,¬†I could stare at it for hours dreaming about kryptonis wheels, trucks and the tricks that folks like Stacy Peralta would pull off.¬† Jumping a car was one thing I always wanted to do, but thankfully didn‚Äôt try.¬† One kid¬†in our pack did attempt the stunt, trying to jump a Honda Civic from front to back and broke his right arm doing so.¬† If you are into boarding you need to check out the G&S site devoted to the Fibreflex series.

To be honest I‚Äôm a little intimidated to get back into the sport again, but the one thing that‚Äôs driving me is Josie.¬† Seattle magazine had a great piece on a father (same age as me) who connected with their son through skateboarding.¬† Josie has also taken on my early love for sports with an edge so I am hoping to get back in the pool again before she is ready to head to the skatepark on a regular basis.

I‚Äôve gone into Zumiez to pick up a board a few times it is a little intimidating as I am not sure what questions to ask anymore. üôÇ¬†If anyone can recommend a decent skateboard shop in the Seattle area with patience for an old fart like me, please let me know.¬† Ron Preston and I at work are actually talking about a trip to the original Zephyr shop in SoCal ‚Äì that place is a landmark for sure.

So the long story short, I am buying a board again, I will suck, but who cares!¬† Seeing the revival of old school boards make it seem like you‚Äôll be seeing more Dads like me are hanging out at the parks and we won‚Äôt be in the benches.¬†

Postscript:¬†My wife adds her thoughts on me getting back into boarding again. üôÇ

item.title: Taking back my blog ‚Äì the fastest year
item.description:
Robert‚Äôs recent blogging about life, his family and more has gotten me to think a lot about what I write here.¬† Every since joining Microsoft almost 10 years ago life has been moving forward at an exagerated pace.¬† In the last 12 months that has intensified even great.¬† Through this past year I have not made any time for blogging aside from an occasional I‚Äôm hiring post and a ‚Äúhey guess what¬†my team has done entry?‚Äù.¬†¬† Unfortunately, here on this site you really isn‚Äôt much here that would tell you about who I am and what a crazy ride that last 12 months have been. üôÇ

That sucks.

So starting today, I‚Äôm taking my blog back with the goal being to tell more about my life, who I am and what makes me tick.¬† This all started when I began to think about the time we‚Äôre living in.¬† I believe that the current technology revolution will be looked at a pivotal point for the world and that through the work I am a part of I‚Äôm helping shape the future.¬† I was thinking the other day about my Grandpa Joe (Josie is named after him) how he lived through the depression as a farmer.¬† He sold the family car to keep food on the table and to allow the kids to remain in school.¬† What would I give to hear about those days, the decisions he made and what was happening around him.¬†

Unfortunately, Granpda Joe died when I was in the 4th grade and aside from old photos and stories from my mom I really don‚Äôt know much more about him.¬† My blog has a new importance in my life and its not necesarily about technology.¬† Moving forward you‚Äôll see more about me, who I am and what I like.¬† My hope at least my kids and theirs will have something to look at.

Turns out after looking at my archives¬†all is not lost¬†I just need to¬†get back in the game.¬† I was parsed thorugh my archives and pulled out some of my favorites posts here from the last 4 years and also over on my wife‚Äôs blog.

item.title: Microsoft 10 is now on the air
item.description:
My team and I have been working night and day for some time to launch an all new community called 10. Our dream is to create a place for those people who want to use technology to change the world.

Every weekday at 10:00 am (PST) we‚Äôll update 10 with a new video that highlights people, their passions and often the technology they are using. At the end of each week we compile these videos into a full length show with some extra surprises for you.

In addition to the show, we‚Äôre launching a number of blogs for the enthusiast covering a wide range of topics. Our blogs will be written by Microsoft employees, members of the 10 community or a mixture of both.

We just posted our first daily show (a little early so we could do some final testing) this weekend which is a trip to KEXP with Laura and Tina¬†who are now a part of my team.¬† You‚Äôll want to tune in each day to get a feel for what the show is all about.¬† Trust me, I think their will be a little of something for everyone it really is a tech variety show.

Tomorrow we‚Äôll post a video to Channel 9 (a sister site of 10) that walks through the technology we used to build 10.¬† In building 10 we paid close attention to the finer details like being able to participate in the conversations while watching a video or little things like pausing the player when you want to sign in to¬†the site.¬† It is a very asynchronous experience.

So we‚Äôre still up tonight, fine tuning the site and bringing to a close a very hard sprint by my team.¬† With any site launch their will be hiccups and bugs, but we‚Äôll fix those and keep moving forward.¬†

The real fun part happens now anyhow,¬†which is taking the feedback from its initial members and adjusting¬†to create a place that everyone wants to be a part of‚Ä¶..

See you on 10!

item.title: Guy on Community ‚Äì I say its like tending bar
item.description:
Guy writes a great piece on the art of building¬†great communities.¬† Lots of good advice.¬†

Reminds me of a piece I wrote sometime ago on my experience of building communities at Microsoft¬†(something I‚Äôve been doing¬†for the last 9 years)¬†¬† When people¬†ask how¬†I do it, I respond, ‚ÄúEverything I learned about building communities I learnt tending bar‚Äú. üôÇ

You can read my¬†complete piece¬†here, but here‚Äôs the key points:

  • A good bartender knows when to be a part of the conversation and when not to.¬† If someone is alone and has no one to talk then the bar staff will often join in and make them feel at home.¬† If the crowd is having fun then they should just sit back and keep the bar clean.¬† That‚Äôs why sometimes we might be part of the conversation or we might just let one go and create a life of its own.
    • Sometimes the role of the staff is just to clean up the mess at the end of the day.¬† On a message board this usually means moving threads to the appropriate forums, deleting spam and fixing broken links in posts.¬†¬† I compare this to when bartenders make sure that the peanuts on the floor don‚Äôt start a fire or that there are no health code violations.¬†
      • Patrons of a bar are free to choose what conversations they have at their table, they can talk about bars where there might be different music, better food or how much they don‚Äôt like the atmosphere of the current place.¬†¬† As long as they are not beligerant to other patrons thats¬†ok.¬†¬†¬†¬† On Channel 9 we have conversations about competing products, our products and even how we can improve.

item.title: Paul Reviews the Google Pack
item.description:
Paul reviews the Google Pack¬†and his conclusion is:

While virtually every computer company on earth is scared to death of Google, and virtually every PC user seems to be in love with them, Google Pack serves nicely as a reality check. Not only is Google human, buts the flaws in Google Pack suggest that this company has a long, long way to go before it can ever justify its insanely lofty stock price. Google Pack is a mixed bag of applications, some useful and some not, though virtually all are deficient in some way as packaged here. I applaud Google for trying to make the PC experience simpler and more secure, but shipping out-of-date security products is even worse than not shipping them at all, because users will get a false sense of security and believe they‚Äôre protected when in fact they are not. Google Pack is still in beta, so the more glaring issues can be fixed by a final release, if there is one. But this initial version of Google Pack is an embarrassment to the company. It‚Äôs just a mess.

Interesting.¬† One of my¬†favorite CES announcements was the addition of Comedy Central to the online spotlight, if you have a media center PC check it out.¬† The user experience is quite slick and you can start to get a feel for where things are going to be when IPTV goes more mainstream.

item.title: 2006 Resolutions
item.description:
Rick puts it best in this classic piece, my favorites are:

Turn down a big VC firm.

Randomly pick a super large VC firm, hit the about our people page, find the ‚Äúassociates‚Äù, and send one a letter declining to allow the firm to participate in your next fund raising. Make it all official like, use buzz words like synergy, web 2.0 personification, and mention that, ‚Äúfrankly that associate of yours really didn‚Äôt understand basics of recurring revenue on a recursive basis.‚Äù Invite them back for an opportunity to discuss your mezzanine round ‚Äúshould someone else in the firm think it is of interest. Your new associate pen pal, looking to climb the corporate VC ladder, will no doubt see this as an amazing opportunity to make one of the other ladder climbing associates look like a dork for missing an opportunity. Expect a call.¬†Great fun for the whole gang.

Actually write a Thank You note.

You know, paper, pen, envelope, stamp.¬† It‚Äôs fun,¬†nostalgic, and the postal service job you save, might just be your own someday.¬† And memo to Marc Orchant of the Tablet PC Weblog: No, handwriting an email note on a Tablet PC does NOT count.

Answer the ‚ÄúPut me in coach‚Äù call.

Somewhere along the line, somebody helped you, offered advice, gave you a break, etc. Do the same. Make 2006 the year you give somebody a break and a chance to get in the game. It could even be the chance you never got, regardless, the world needs lots of smart people making more smart people.

Awesome post, Rick.¬† So here‚Äôs to 2005 and to a great 2006 as I sit with Josie (who‚Äôs staying up way to late Watching Scooby Doo on Nick), my wife who‚Äôs participating in some discussion on a political message board and me here writing a blog post.¬† Man, hard to believe I am nearing the end of a 2 week vacation filled with board games and of course lots of XBOX 360.¬† Wouldn‚Äôt trade all this in for the world.

So yes, I‚Äôve been absent from posting lately here and have gotten a number of private notes asking when I‚Äôll be writing again?¬† (Yes all 5 of my readers wrote in üòâ Yes, I‚Äôm doing great!

item.title: Harmony 880 Remote
item.description:
I recently purchased an Harrmony 880 remote, man what an excellent purchase.¬† Two pictures are worth a thousand words:

¬†

Before

After

The Harmony 880 Advanced Universal Remote makes my home theater much easier to use as it combines the remotes for my XBox, Media Center PC, Plasma, Comcast HD DVR, Component Video Switchbox and Bose Lifestyle system into one remote.¬† I‚Äôve seen lots of universal remotes in the past but there are few things that make this one a buy in my house.

1. Price
2. Scenario based
3. Broad Range Device Support
4. WAF

**Price
** I didn‚Äôt want to spend¬†a $1000.00 for¬†a remote control, it just seems absurd to spend that one.¬† This remote can be purchased for $250.00 at Best Buy or for $175.00 if you shop around the web. Great deal.

**Scenario Based
** This was the clincher for me.¬† The LCD display selects user defined scenarios like Play a game, Watch a DVD, or Watch TV and executes on the results.¬†

For example selecting watch TV on my system does the following: It turns on my plasma setting the input to number 4, changes my component video switcher to input 2, sets my BOSE Lifestyle unit to TV and turns on my Comcast PVR.¬† Very cool!¬†¬†

Another example is I have the Harmony programmed so that when I select Listen to music it turns my Bose Lifestyle to Auxilary, my plasma to input 3 and navigates on the media center to my music.

I have similar functions defines for Play a game (XBox) and also for watching movies on DVD.

This works great.

**Broad Range Device Support
** The unit supports every device I own, even the Calrad IR controlled component video switchbox.¬† It appears from the only forums that Logitech regularly updates their device library with new devices.¬† I recommend that you write down the model numbers of your devices prior to getting started with the remote setup.¬† Makes it a lot easier.

**WAF
** The Wife Acceptance Factor is high.¬† One button how shuts our entire system down, she can turn on games for my daughter or even listen to music on the media center.¬† Previous to this¬†I had diagram and instructions inside our entertainment cabinet that rivaled a power plant.

Nits? Yes I have one.¬† The remote uses a hybrid web / client application to program the application.¬† You go through a series of ASP pages to select options, specify devices, etc when you‚Äôre ready to update the remote, you plug it into your USB port on your machine and you download a data file to your local machine.¬† It works pretty well but I‚Äôd prefer a full Windows client to program the device.¬† Here‚Äôs a perfect example of where a smart client that communicates via Web Services would be ideal.¬† If by chance your work for Logitech on the Harmony project and want to chat further, send me an email to jeffsand at microsoft dot com. üôÇ

Anyhow, if you‚Äôre looking for a remote this one is a winner..

Postscript: Many moons later, I‚Äôve now purchased an 890 remote from Harmony.

Enjoy!

item.title: MSN Desktop Search is a Seven Day Winner
item.description:
I‚Äôm getting some heat by Ross Jones in the comments for my post about the MSN Screensaver that it requires the MSN Toolbar to function.

Whilst I don‚Äôt want to rain on your parade isn‚Äôt putting functionality (search) on a screensaver fairly pointless? Do you tend to sit and try and use your computer when the screensaver is on? Personally the only time I ever see it is when I come back to my computer and press space to re-activate it.

And besides that ain‚Äôt a screensaver http://www.engadget.com/entry/1234000807035571/ is a screensaver üôÇ Just don‚Äôt ask how many lines of code were written to do this, you wouldn‚Äôt like the answer üôÇ

Sorry, I didn‚Äôt realize MSN Toolbar to be installed as MSN Desktop Search is a key part of software arsenal. It passed my

7 Days of Software Rule easily. Google Desktop didn‚Äôt fare so well, it lasted on my sytem less than a day before it was uninstalled.

You see I don‚Äôt want to go to a webpage to search for my data on my local system and if I need an indexer on my local machine, it better be gentle enough to run on my Vaio laptop. Google failed me on both of those accounts.

What are some of the reasons I love MSN Desktop?

Well the wordwheel that gets built into the Windows Taskbar rocks! I can access search whenever I need it. It really has changed how I work with Outlook. Now it doesn‚Äôt matter anymore how I classify information in Outlook, no crazy Outlook folder heirarchy as MSN Desktop Search never lets me down in finding even the most obscure item from Outlook.

MSN Desktop Search Word Wheel

Once I get a result set out of desktop search (it is very fast) I get a Windows Client view (not a webpage) that I can quick move around and get previews of the documents I am looking at as opposed to the Google way of using a browser.

Also the indexer is very gentle, I am running it on my Sony Vaio laptop and no performance problems.

As for the question is search useful in a screensaver (Sorry I forgot to answer that in my first time around this post). For me its great to have search on a screensaver (especially now the MSN Search is giving me much better results :-)). You see I keep a laptop always open in my kitchen and by having it go to a sexy screensaver like MSN Search with news, weather and cool photos from is great improvement on my kitchen counter.¬† But its not jsut that, search is the most used application on this machine. We use it to find recipes, phone numbers and movie times. By having search on a screensaver, it saves me a step as it is now always there.

Anyhow, pick your software wisely and think about the Seven Day Rule. I feel that is a definite

MSN Desktop Search is the winner over Google Desktop Search¬†and heck you can even use a cool RSS Screensaver.

item.title: Software as a service
item.description:
I cut my teeth in .NET working with a fellow by the name of Garland Brown on a project where we wrapped Microsoft‚Äôs internal Siebel implementation as a web service.

.NET Undocument writes an interesting history of the road to Getting Web Services:

The notion of ‚Äúsoftware as a service‚Äù has gradually become a coherent and unifying story throughout Microsoft. I see it in the .NET framework support for web services and ClickOnce, in Indigo‚Äôs¬†attempts to unify the various Windows communications approaches into a simple, common services-based API, in¬†Avalon‚Äôs borrowing of UI patterns (deployment, inductive UI, markup, navigation) from the Web. I sense it¬†in Office 12‚Äôs continued movement towards XML and network-centric computing, and in Microsoft‚Äôs recent embrace of RSS. I can only extrapolate this to the rest of Microsoft‚Äôs divisions.

It was fun times and some of the most rewarding work I‚Äôve done in my career at Microsoft working on a project we call ‚ÄúThe Factory‚Äù. Months and years afterwards we went around the country talking about Web Services in the Enterprise long before SOA and Enteprise Service Bus were the rage.

Fun times.

item.title: Offsite Meets Foo Camp
item.description:
We had a great offsite today for the Channel 9 Team. At Microsoft an offsite is a meeting where you take the team away from the normal settings and do some planning.

Offsites serve as a a great way to get everyone away from email, the daily routines and devote a solid day to planning. From my previous experience at offsites you never quite know what you‚Äôll get out of an offsite. My hope is that we‚Äôll build relationships amongst team members, exchange ideas, hopefully a few unexpected gems come out in the day and if we‚Äôre focussed get away with some things we can turn into actionable plans.

For today‚Äôs team I tried something different, instead of a rigid schedule that I predefined in advance we spent the first hour of the meeting as a team triaging topics that we needed to work through in the day. I had some must have topics that I brought forward that got in the agenda, Charles, Robert, Beth and Adam also brought some as well to the table. We triaged them, assigned a priority brainstormed on what the issues were and consolidate them into a session. We then built out the agenda for the day as a team deciding what to hit first, second, etc.

The day went very well, we moved from brainstorming mode and really got through a lot of issues. Its surprising what a simple change of environment can do to help you focus and I think building out the agenda as a team really helped everyone feel involved.¬† Sort of like Foo Camp Meets Offsite.

We got through all the things we set out to do today, by the end of the day we had clear owners to sponsor invidivual items, plenty of great ideas and sponsors for each. We‚Äôll now move these into project mode and be on our way.

We‚Äôll share more with you via Channel 9 as we get into the feedback phase for the plans, but for now I must say how excited I am about what we‚Äôve got in store.¬†It is going to be a great year on Channel 9.

item.title: The New Mustang Rocks
item.description:
I‚Äôm thinking (I repeat thinking) about buying a new car and am looking for something fun. Recently while in California I noticed a new mustang that had some styling effects and alluminum wheels that made it really stand out.

Turns out the car was no ordinary Mustang, it was a Saleen Mustang.¬† A company with a long heritage of crafting beautiful cars, what Saleen does to the Mustang GT is amazing.

  • Custom forged 7-spoke 20‚Ä≥ x 9 allow wheels
    • Saleen‚Äôs microchip improvements along with a free-flowing air filter bring 400 horses under the hood
      • Suspension improvements ‚Äì springs, shocks, and anti-roll bars and pivot bushings

        • Free flowing exhaust improvments

          • Interior guaging improvements and seat updates
          That just some of the stuff they do to a stock Mustang, there‚Äôs much more, click around here for a better look (you can even hear the roar of the engine).

        Man, its been hard to get details on the Saleens from a customer perspective, as Jason Calcanis mentions spam is taking over the blog search sites making it impossible to find any information from the blogs on popular consumer products. (Hey MSN Search Team Opportunity Knocks. If you search for Saleen Mustang on all the major blog search engines instead of information from owners you are returned SPAM from folks trying to increase their Google page rank. I did find some decent information on Autoblog for an original mustang which was Ok.

        Yesterday I drove out to Bickford Ford in Snohomish, WA which is one of Washington States largest Saleen Dealers and took one for a test drive. Oh my God! What an unbelievable car! There‚Äôs a reason that every single 2005 Mustang that comes off the assembly line is spoken for.

        Ford has a winner here! Saleen takes it over the top!¬†

        Getting behind the wheel it felt like I was in a muscle car. I was a little skeptical of the retro look of the car and wondered if it was all looks and no action. As soon as I got behind the wheel, powered it up, it brought back all sorts of memories of a friends ‚Äô69 Mustang from high school. This is a muscle car.

        I took the car out for about 30 minutes, scooting down the highway, working through the gears. The car handled really well and I still have a grin on my face from the experience. I‚Äôm trying rationalize right now the Saleen vs. a stock GT with Allow Rims and a microchip (purchased seperately from Saleen) not sure if all the extras Saleen brings to the table are worth it, but man what a car!

        If anyone out there has bought a 2005 Mustang GT, let me know what you think. I‚Äôll link back and consolidate the views.
