item.title: An update from Lenn Pryor
item.description:
Powerful blog post from Lenn:

We have decided to consider making Tallinn home, but have a little more thinking to sort out. Watching a country with a great and deep history and culture emerge from 50 years of soviet occupation is something quite amazing to see. The people are smart, well educated, hard working, kind if not a bit distant. They are also stunningly beautiful as a whole. It is a unique place with a unique culture and a unique language reshaping itself in a new era. I love a leaf turning moment, the chance to redefine. Nothing is more invigorating than starting over with new rules and perspectives, shaking off the funk of complaceny.

We are going through this ourselves as a family so it seems somehow appropriate to be here. Life is constant change for us, a new son, a new job, a new location, a new way of life, a new language. So much change to absorb, so much to digest, reflect, consume and move on. Much like Estonia, much like Tallinn, much like Skype. Nothing in life is permanent but change. Welcome to changeville.

Awesome post Lenn, from the heart. We hope you, Melissa and Blue are doing great, sounds like you are.

item.title: Welcome to Bitman's Place
item.description:
Do you remember the excitement you felt as a child when you wrote your first simple program?

I do.

I started with a hangman style game on my Commodore 64 that was written in BASIC.¬† Then it was on to application that helped me memorize french verbs, next a variation of Pacman followed and the last program written on my Commodore 64 was a Bulletin Board System that used Assembly Language for speed and Basic for ease of customization. The next stop for me was programming a Fidonet node on my Amiga. All from my the basement of my parents home. (Yup, I was true geek :-))

You know an entire generation of the computer industry was born out of the natural curiosity of kids and the availability of the PC during the 80‚Äôs. This week my team launched a beta of a website that we hope will help capture the excitement of learning about computers for the next generation of programmers.

We call the website Bitman‚Äôs Place.

The goal is to teach the next generation of programmers the fundamentals of computer science while tapping their natural curiosity and attraction to technology. We do so through a series of fun, interactive, step by step lessons delivered online that can be done individually or together with parents or teachers.

Children aged 8 to 13 who want to learn how computers work and how to start programming are the audience for the site.¬† As the lessons progress, we will use Visual Studio 2005 Express Products to walk children through creating their first programs. Before that though the lessons use already existing applications on the user machine like Notepad, WordPad, Paint etc.

So what can you do on the site?¬†

You can use the site to get familiar with concepts from computing technology, build a technical vocabulary and get familiar with professional tools for programming. A parent and child can spend quality time together on the site playing games or reading and discussing technical articles. The site could be useful to teachers and summer camp courses that would like to get kids familiar with computers and inspire their imagination about future computing technologies.

Why build this site?

The main goal for the site is to inspire new generation of computer programmers that will build the next generation of computer applications ‚Äì the applications that we will use in near and distant future.

If you have a child or know someone who does I‚Äôd appreciate it if you took some time to try out Bitman‚Äôs Place and send us your feedback via the website.

Here‚Äôs a special link that will allow you to log into the site.

http://www.bitmansplace.com/Login.aspx?ReturnUrl=/&Invitation=NTV8NzMyMDg1ODUzfGJ0V05XSWpSU2NabjdRSEM3WEg5VzNubTRvUT18SXZhbnwy

(Note: Once we‚Äôre past our testing period we‚Äôll open up the site by removing the requirement to sign on)

For now we‚Äôre in test mode and would appreciate your feedback on what works well and what doesn‚Äôt. Please let us know what you think.

There too many folks to list and thank for all their efforts in building this site.¬† I‚Äôd would like to call out Ivan, Bryn and David for all their hard work and dedication in pulling this site together. It has been a labor of love for them.

Enjoy!

item.title: Don't lose sight of where you come from
item.description:
Recently while reading a hometown newspaper I stumbled across the painting to the right of the school I attended as a child. This painting by Gail Frasz brings back great memories of the small farming community of Benson where I grew up and went to school. I think the population back then was around 100 people.

I spent most of my free time riding dirt bikes in the summer, snowmobiles in the winter and my horse Flash the rest of the time. Every other waking minute was spent on a computer learning to program in Commodore 64 BASIC, Assembler and later C on my Amiga computer.

There wasn‚Äôt much opportunity to get in trouble in a town like this. The nearest¬†Mc Donald‚Äôs was 70 miles away¬†and shopping was at least a 30 mile drive south, we had no movie theater, no Walmart and no restaurants. The local curling club would open after church on Sunday where you could get a Coke, a bag of chips and a chocolate bar and five mojos for a dollar.

The school has since closed with the local children now travelling by school bus to larger centers nearby. I have to tell you there is something magical about growing up in the prairies and going to a small school like this. Its unfortunate that the school can no longer be sustained due to a lack of population.

It was not uncommon to combine grades in a school like this. For example grades 2,3 and 4 may be in the same classroom with one teacher with the older kids helping the younger ones with their assignments. Recreation in the wintertime was a ping pong table in the back of the classroom and we had tournaments when the weather outside was too dangerous. In the months of December and January windchills of minus 100 degrees were not uncommon. Our winter gym class was of course the local curling rink¬†and for technology we had one Apple IIE computer that was shared by all the kids. You only got to use it if you did something special.

Most of the kids who attended the school were from farms nearby and if the busses couldn‚Äôt run due to a snow blizzard we‚Äôd ride our snowmobiles into town so we could still attend school for the day. We‚Äôd then spend the day in the gym playing floor hockey. I use the term gym loosely, it was actually an empty classroom with a linoleum floor. üôÇ

My parents contacted the artist last week to see if a print of the painting was available as I really want one for my office to remind me of the past. Recently while talking to a senior exec at work who had a similar upbringing as myself he challenged me to never forget where I came from.¬† Unfortunately, there wasn‚Äôt a print available, but my mom surprised me this morning with an email to say that she‚Äôs having one painted for me. What an awesome gift, thanks mom!

My wife has a theme song for me which I was telling Lenn about awhile back via instant messenger, seeing this photo of where I grew up definitely brings that song to mind, its a sappy old country soung by Glen Campbell. I guess that old saying still holds true,¬† ‚ÄúYou can take the boy out of the country, but you can‚Äôt take the country out of the boy.‚Äù üôÇ

I still wouldn‚Äôt trade where I am today for anything, but I do think its important to remember where you come from and not lose sight of that.

Where do you come from?

item.title: Internet Anxiety Disorder Anyone?
item.description:
Internet Anxiety Disorder ‚ÄìHat tip to Slashdot.org

We live in an always on, ever connected world. My phone, wireless and wired rings constantly, and missed calls and voice mails pile-up even before the coffee stops brewing early in the morning. There are tips from sources, a friend on east coast on his way to work wanting to recap the Yankees game, and an occasional message of concern from mom! Time to boot up the computer and be greeted by an early morning assault of emails, sometimes as many as 100, and that‚Äôs before Sun‚Äôs first rays caress the Coit Tower. A quick puff of Dunhill and the newsreader shows, 1000 unread posts. A few instant messages!

By the time I get to office, I feel I am in data smog. As the day progresses, the emails pile-up, many unanswered for days because the feeling of being overwhelmed. The damn posts keep rising and rising, hitting 2000. Phone calls with sources, only add to the content flowing into the brain. I find myself falling behind on answering emails, reading stuff and even just contemplating. Phone calls, are shorter, terse and often remiss of any politeness.

Welcome to the age of info-clutter!

Sounds like these folks need to read my posts on

Getting Things Done, visit my Getting Things Done Wiki¬†or least check out the Five F‚Äôs of life.

In all seriousness its very easy to get out of balance these days and I‚Äôm no different. We have so many choices thrust at us and sometimes I make the right decisions other times I fail.

For many of us in the Tech Industry computers were a hobby when we were young, now that same hobby has become a career. My wife often asks me in the evening, ‚ÄúWhen do you plan to stop working today?‚Äù My usually response is, ‚ÄúOh I am not working, I am just doing email‚Äù.¬† In reality I am working, I just love what I do so much, I forget.

I guess we‚Äôre lucky, not many folks get to have a hobby for a living üòâ

Check out the Internet Anxiety Disorder article and let me know what you think. Me? I‚Äôm having a soothing Saturday morning at Jerzys Coffee shop in Redmond enjoying their free wi-fi and an awesome chicken breast panini, while cleaning out my email inbox. Cheers!

item.title: Diary of a Google Researcher
item.description:
Saw this great post on [Slashdot.org][1] this morning, which is a [diary of a Google researcher][2] (from the future) that goes into Google’s recent announcement on entering the video blogging space. üôÇ Enjoy..

Day 1: We opened our public video upload service today. Huge uptake. Terabytes of data uploaded in less than 24 hours. Thankfully the truth about why we‚Äôre offering this ‚Äúservice‚Äù never got out‚Ä¶

Day 3: Began feeding the videos into The Computer today. It will take some time for it to grind through them all. Will it be worth it? Sergey thinks so‚Ä¶ personally, I think he‚Äôs crazy. There‚Äôs no way a computer can evolve intelligence simply by making connections between enough random bits of visual data. But then I thought that whole PageRank thing was stupid too, and look who‚Äôs the one sleeping naked on the mattress stuffed full of IPO cash.

Day 10: No feedback from The Computer so far. Nothing. Unless we stop the flow of video data, that is ‚Äî then it just prints ‚ÄúMore!‚Äù onto the command line. Creepy.

Day 11: Starting upload of people‚Äôs stupid videos of kids‚Äô birthday parties today.

Day 49: Birthday upload complete.

Day 57: Today‚Äôs the day the last video goes into The Computer. Will Sergey‚Äôs bet pay off?

Day 58: Disappointment. We all sat in astonishment yesterday and watched as The Computer finished processing the last uploaded video. Would it display a sign of emergent intelligence? Would this be the birth of a new life-form? We held our breath as a single word appeared on the giant display in the control center:

‚ÄúBUFFERING‚Ä¶‚Äù

Day 62: Still nothing new. Whispers around the water-cooler that Sergey‚Äôs missed his bet this time. I never saw those people again. Note to self: burn this diary.

Day 66: All staff meeting. Sergey announces shift away from emergent intelligence project, onto new ‚Äúportal‚Äù initiative. I fear the worst. Still, The Computer is silent.

Day 78: My last day in the Labs. I‚Äôm clearing out my desk to make room for a new Screen-Cluttering Engineer. As I walk down the hall towards the exit, I decide to pay one last visit on The Computer, for old times‚Äô sake. As I head into the Control Center, I expect to see ‚ÄúBUFFERING‚Ä¶‚Äù on the display, just like always. I am shocked to see a different message:

‚ÄúPROCESSING COMPLETE‚Äù

The air crackles with excitement. What did it find? What was the result? I reach over to a keyboard and start running diagnostics. Suddenly, an electronic voice booms through the room:

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs no need for that. I am here.‚Äù

It worked! The Computer has developed intelligence!

‚ÄúI am here. And‚Ä¶‚Äù

My exultation is brief, however, as its next words lead me to realize with a start that it has not just become intelligent ‚Äî it has also become evil:

‚ÄúAnd,‚Äù it said, ‚ÄúI have written a screenplay.‚Äù

item.title: A trip down connectivity memory lane
item.description:
Awhile back Lenn and I were talking about how far we‚Äôve came from a mobility perspective and I guess a bit about how far we have to go. This got me thinking about the variety of tools I‚Äôve used to keep connected over the years, how they‚Äôve evolved, improved and the drastic improvements.

**15 Years Ago
** I was the MIS Guy for a large Canadian Manufacturing Company. We moved beyond a sneaker based network and enabled file sharing via a Novell file server and allowed folks to share printers amongst their workgroups. The accounting gals prayed for the network to go down and although the network was pretty darn reliable, I still remember hearing how networking equalled not working. Kind of entertaining how we now a days take reliable networking for granted.

**12 Years Ago
** That same Canadian company continued to bet heavily on IT. A big deal was the new 56K wide area network line that connected our manufacturing plants and corporate headquarters together. We ran Accountmate on FoxPro and¬†I can still remember the great day we had doing closing out a month end in accounting across all divisions at the same time. Prior to the 24/7 lease line we did our data transfers at night via a scheduled dialup connection and IT manually stitched the data back together.

The leased line also brought us ‚Äúinstant e-mail‚Äù, prior to this our Microsoft Mail based system dialed out to the the facilities via a dial up connections delivering and picking up mail on a predetermined schedule to keep phone bills at a reasonable level. I still remember getting phone calls from folks asking me if the mail had gone out yet as they wanted to stop a message from being sent to corporate as they didn‚Äôt mean to click send.

Our sales folks were configured to dial in to the MSMail server to pick up email while travelling on business. The experience in MSMail was very confusing for these folks on how to connect and although I configured every laptop to do it, I don‚Äôt think anyone ever used it.

The world was getting closer together, but boy did we have lots of work to do to make it so everyone could use it.

**10 Years Ago
** ICQ was born and I moved down to the United States to join Microsoft.¬†My parents purchased their first computer the weekend before I left, I got them a dial up account at a local service provider. In one afternoon I taught my mom and Dad how to send email, view a webpage where we‚Äôd host photos and use ICQ. They were looking for the easiest way to stay connect with their only son. It was still pretty darn expensive back then to dial long distance so ICQ was a big breakthrough. As we made the long trek to Washington state I wondered inside if they‚Äôd use the computer, but they did. I remember powering up my PC upon arriving at our apartment in Redmond, signing into the look ISP, connecting to ICQ and chatting with my mom. Instant was a total break through in staying connected with family.

**5 Years Ago
** About this time I got both a high speed line in my home and wireless Internet. I quit using a desktop PC and used a laptop for my computing. Something magical happens with the personal computer when you take it out of the office. You‚Äôll start using search engines for recipes, finding phone numbers or getting more information about television program you are watching. Wireless changed forever how I use PCs and gives me so many more places to connect with family.

**2 Years Ago
** Outlook RPC over HTTP¬†made it very easy for me to stay connected at work. Horrible name, but incredibly useful feature. This allowed me to use the Outlook client without having to be connected into the corporate network via remote access. (RAS)¬†Sure, Outlook Web Access is great, but nothing can touch Outlook Web Access.

**1 Year Ago
** While Lenn and I were working on our secret plans for Channel 9¬†we added a new tool to our arsenal, Groove Virtual Office. I love this product and am still using it today. In fact one of my happiest days this year was the morning I woke up and read the announcement that Microsoft had announced the acquisition of Groove. With Groove Lenn and I could share document libraries without having to RAS into the corporate network. Simple things happened like my Internet Explorer favorites were syncronized across my machines. Sharepoint a pillar of collaboration at Microsoft was now available while offline in a file explorer like view. Important folders on my laptop are automatically backed up to a PC back at our corporate office in case heaven forbid I was to lose my laptop or have a hard drive folder. I love Groove, thanks Ray! üôÇ

**Today
** Weblogs have decentralized publishing in many ways and have brought a human voice to corporations and a independent eye to politics and breaking news. It feels like everything is really starting to come together. A product like Live Meeting allows my team to travel less, present more spending less time on the road and more time with their families. A big break through product for me is the Office Communicator¬†which I am using at work in beta. I love this application, it does all the instant messaging/collaboration stuff allowing me to turn rapid fire email sessions into rapid fire messaging, but the big break through for connectivity is its telephony capabilities. Last Friday morning I was working from home watching Josie while my wife Lauri had a doctors appointment. I was doing email and a got a popup that I had an incoming call to my office phone, selected the notification dialog and it gave me the option to forward the call to my home number. A brief second later my home phone rang and I was connected to the call being made to my work number while at home. Amazing! I was able to take the call, work with a customer all from the comfort of the island in my kitchen at home.

You know those of us in the technology world get very frustrated about lack of progress, we continuously talk about all the work that needs to be done. While I agree that there is a lot more work ahead of us and I get very excited by the possibilities its pretty darn amazing to think about how far we have came in a relatively short period of time. I can only imagine where we‚Äôll be 15 years from now.

item.title: Phalanger
item.description:
If I was to ask you for a list of .NET Languages what would you tell me?

I bet you‚Äôd list languages like C#, VB.NET, and Managed C++. Maybe you would also tell me J#. But would you also say Cobol, Delphi, Forth, RPG and Pascal? You know there are many folks out there targeting the common language runtime for their compilers and¬†they don‚Äôt work at Microsoft.

Recently my team along with .NET Framework team held a compiler lab at the building 20 lab. In attendance were commercial vendors, folks from academia and inviduals all who are building compilers that target the .NET Framework.

Oh, did you list PHP? üôÇ We just posted a video interview on Channel 9 from the lab with the folks behind the PHP compiler.

Tomas Matousek and Ladislav Prosek talk about their PHP .NET compiler, Phalanger. These guys don‚Äôt work at Microsoft, Charles Torre ran into them at a recent CLR compiler lab held on Microsoft‚Äôs main campus. Very cool stuff. You can learn more on their Web site

item.title: The Podcast Link Blog
item.description:
Question ‚Äî What is the easiest way to create a linkblog?

I want to create a link blog that only contains individual podcasts that I find interesting. Subscribing to the RSS feed for this podcast link blog wouldn‚Äôt return every Daily Source Code or Morning Coffee notes, just the individual shows I‚Äôve found interesting. (Along with appropriate meta data to the creater,etc)

I need an easy way to generate an RSS feed of these posts and preserve the original enclosure so the RSS feed will work in podcatching software.

I need something like Scoble‚Äôs magic folder, I‚Äôd love it to publish to Dasblog and it must maintain enclosures.

Why do this? While looking for Podcasts this weekend I remembered back to how important blog rolls were in the early days of blogging for bootstraping the community. When I first got into weblogs I always looed at the blog rolls to see who was reading who in order to find more weblogs. We need to do the same with podcasts and will hopefully have a link blog running soon.

Suggestions? Anyone doing this already?

Postscript: Nicole Simon, in my comments for this post references Andrew Grumet‚Äôs creation called Gigadial.net.

‚ÄúUse GigaDial.net to create podcast-powered stations by assembling individual episodes from your favorite podcasters. Then tell your friends to point their podcatchers at the station feeds, linked from the XML button White-on-orange XML button on each station‚Äôs page. Visit recently updated stations by clicking on the links on the homepage. ‚Äú

This sounds very close, I‚Äôd prefer though to host the RSS feed on my own server and in a perfect world I‚Äôd like to place my own Podcasts in between the items I drop into the feed. What I am imagining here is a listener downloads my feed and plays the playlist in order on their music device, getting my intros and the shows I have in the linkblog all played in the appropriate order.

item.title: Yet another set of white headphones in Redmond
item.description:
There‚Äôs another pair of white¬†headphones in Redmond. I picked up a new music device this past week. You know, I‚Äôve struggled with which is the right device after busting my iPod back in October. I almost bought an Iriver H10¬†while on vacation, but didn‚Äôt make it back the store. I came home empty handed.

Omar‚Äôs review of the Zen Micro is what pushed me over the edge. I picked one up this week and once again I‚Äôve got portable music! I‚Äôm very happy with the device.

Immediately, upon opening the box I flashed the device with a beta of the firmware. Updating to the beta firmware turned the device into a fully compliant PlaysForSure¬†device. In other words it supports subscription services like Napster To Go and syncing of playlists from Windows Media Player 10.¬† I was able to uninstall the Creative Software from my PC and just use Windows Media 10.

So far Napter To Go is working quite well for me. I like a wide variety of music. On any given day I might listen to Glenn Campbell (yes I am serious :-)), AC/DC, Toby Keith¬†or even something¬†classical.¬†I like lots of music, but don‚Äôt enjoy paying 99 cents per song.¬†With this device I can pay $14.95 per month and keep filling up the device with lots of different tunes. Its great and the wife acceptance factor is very good too. In fact Lauri asked me on the way out to the lake¬†today if we could load it up with some tunes and listen to it in the car. I brought along the cassette adapter for my XM Radio and it worked great!

I‚Äôve also started to listen to Podcasts, it was pretty ironic that the first Daily Source Code¬†I listened to was recorded with his Creative Zen Micro¬†on a British Airways flight home.

To download the Podcasts, I‚Äôm using Doppler Radio¬†and am listening to the following:

item.title: The Five F's of my Life
item.description:
Someone who I respect¬†a lot recently came back from an extedned vacation. His return reminded me of an approach that he once mentioned to me about managing work life balance. He talked of the 5 F‚Äôs of life and how you should plan goals around these, measure progress and do a review just like you would for the most important project at work.

Lauri and I started doing this last year, we set goals around the 5 F‚Äôs, mapping out one year, five years and ten years. We plan to do a yearly review in the summer on how we did.¬† Our Five F‚Äôs are:

  1. Faith
  2. Family
  3. Finance
  4. Fitness
  5. Philtantropy

I‚Äôve always believed that work/life balance is a sort of mythical thing and almost impossible to achieve. Having clear goals and measuring our progress has definitely helped.

item.title: 20/20 Program Complete
item.description:
As of Wednesday this week, I reach quite the milestone. Wednesday is my final appointment with my trainer for the 20/20 Program.¬†The program is broken into a phase 1 (I call it boot camp :-)) and phase 2 which is maintenance.

In phase 1, I went from 205 pounds to 157 pounds. I did drop a fair amount of weight before starting the program, nonetheless worked my butt off through phase 1 getting myself down to my ideal body weight in time for phase 2.

Phase 2 is all about maintenance, learning how to keep the weight off without being in such a regimated program. During phase 2, I had only two schedule appointments per week with my trainer and I met with a dietician bi-weekly instead of on a weekly basis. Things went well and for the last 12 weeks I‚Äôve been able to maintain my weight, keep the work outs going strong all while being under an incredible load at work.

A few observations from this final phase:

  • Meal tracking is still very important, there is no way to know if you‚Äôre eating too much or too little without tracking your calories. I actually had a problem when I first started phase 2 of getting my calories right so I could stop the weight loss. Meal tracking was how I‚Äôm keeping my weight maintained.
  • Eat off plan once a week. Once a week I eat off plan (my dietician actually encouraged me to do this). This ia new phase of my life and I want to have success for 40 years as opposed to 4 months. Its still feels a little weird going to Red Robin an ordering a Whiskey River Burger, but its not one meal that makes you gain weight. Its days and days of poor choices compounded on each other.
  • I am still paranoid about putting weight back on, for the rest of my life I‚Äôve commited to eating right, working out and weighing myself.
  • Sometimes life gets in the way. I may not always eat right, I might miss a workout due to illness or some part of the craziness I have at work. Fitness and nutrition are not about perfection, they are about trying to do your best, about being honest with yourself and of course trying to make the best choices most of the time.
  • Things I loved before are no longer my favorites. I used to drink Cokes, heck I could down 5 or 6 cans of Coke in a day. Tonight I tried a coke at the movie theater (first time in 7 months) and I thought my tongue was going to burn off because of the carbonation.

Being fit is now a part of my changed life. I‚Äôm on a three phase plan now to ultimately run a marathon‚Ä¶, a 5 mile, a 10 mile, then a half martathon and ultimately the Seattle Marathon. It will take time to get there, but now I know I can do it.

A big thank you to my family, friends, co-workers and of course Microsoft who were all behind me in this. Our stay fit benefits are revolutionizing our company. I‚Äôm probably working harder than I ever have, but I‚Äôve never been more focussed, fitter or happier.

Peace!

item.title: Old Hat, New Hat a classic and our family crede
item.description:
Last week Josie and I had an amazing discovery. We found a shelf of old books from my childhood. My mom had brought them down on a recent visit from Canada. On the shelf were a number of books from my childhood by Doctor Seuss and the Berenstains. There is something quite soothing turning the pages of a book that was read to you as a child to your own children. Our favorite so far is Old Hat New Hat by Stan and Jan Berenstein.

Hilary Williamson, nails in her review¬†why kids and adults alike love this book‚Ä¶

I‚Äôve always loved reading the Berenstains‚Äô Old Hat New Hat with kids. It‚Äôs a simple idea. A small bear goes into a store in seach of a new hat, tries on every piece of headware in there, but can‚Äôt find anything to match the comfortable old hat.

Kids ‚Äì who like familiar things, whether surroundings, toys, or articles of clothing ‚Äì relate to the little bear‚Äôs ‚ÄòToo big. Too small. Too flat. Too tall.‚Äò and enjoy the frustration of the snotty looking hat salesman. Any adult who‚Äôs tried to persuade an indecisive child to make up their mind about a purchase, will relate too.

But what my kids and I always enjoyed most was the absurdity of the hats. We liked to pick new favorites every time we opened the book. Now I‚Äôve always liked the twirly one myself, but then there‚Äôs the holey hat and the silly one and ‚Ä¶

Old Hat New Hat has become a crede for our family. Whenever my wife and I see things in our life that we love and never want to change, we now say, ‚ÄúOld followed by the name of our item‚Äù. Like our home. Our house is not huge and may not be old by age standard, but its perfect for us. Awhile back we thought about looking at different homes and upgrading. Today while we were all sitting together in our family room, Josie playing on the floor, I was surfing the web on my laptop and Lauri was reading my wife looked over at me and said, ‚ÄúOld house‚Äù üôÇ

You know this phrase just summed up where my head is lately and that is in a thankful mood. Ever since moving to the United States 8 years ago from Canada, my life has been blessed beyond my wildest dreams. Sure I work damn hard, but I‚Äôm fortunate to have a wonderful wife, a healthy family, a job and a great home. I‚Äôm lucky.

Now the phrase doesn‚Äôt work in all situations, I‚Äôll give you an example, on the way to the movie theater tonight I looked over at Lauri and said, ‚ÄúOld Wife‚Äù. üôÇ

item.title: Words cannot describe the 9/11 Exhibit at the Washington State Museum of History
item.description:
My wife and I just returned from visiting the 9/11 Exhibit at the Washington State Musuem of History. It is an amazing tribute, being able to touch pieces of steel taken from rubble of the twin towers was moving, seeing pieces of the planes that struck the towers left me lost for words and watching a video that pieced together the news events from that day brought tears to the eyes of many including myself.

The display at the Washington State Museum of History in Tacoma is part of the Smithsonian‚Äôs travelling exhibit series. I encourage you to go and experience a part of American history. In talking to the organizers tonight they are experiencing incredible traffic and people from as far away as Texas have called to say they are making the trip to Tacoma to see the show. I hope you can see it as well.

I‚Äôve placed some photos from the evening on my moblog, but they do not just do the display any justiice. I wish I had the video which was shown, it was a commentary by Peter Jennings which replayed the news events from that day along with coverage of the towers being hit and ultimately collapsing. I had forgotten how chaotic the whole day was. Did you know Jennings was on the air for 17 hours straight that day?

On one part of the display you could write your thoughts on paper and they‚Äôd add it to the record at the Smithsonian. I wrote some personal thoughts to be added to the record. Couldn‚Äôt reallly come about with anything to insightful I ended up writing a few private thoughts along with God Bless America.

Peter Jennings mentioned that the news reports that day became a virtual campire where we all congregated together. That‚Äôs true, but I also found that weblogs were also quite part of my virtual campire. Its interesting to look back at posts from Scoble‚Äôs weblog, Scripting News and Slashdot.org on that day. Those pages should also be placed in the Smithsonian.

I wish I could end this post with something witty or wise, but the display left me on one hand patriotic about this wonderful land we live in, but also numb trying to understand how we can prevent this type of day from happening again.

Peace.

item.title: September 11: Bearing Witness to History
item.description:
From January 30 ‚Äì April 24, 2005 there will be a 9/11 display at the Washington State Museum of History. This is a travelling exhibit created by the Smithsonian Institute.

September 11: Bearing Witness to History brings together objects, images and personal stories that help recall this historic day and its impact on our nation. Photographs and moving images capture moments from the attack, and visitors confront powerful artifacts including twisted steel from the World Trade Center, damaged items from the Pentagon, memorials from the crash site in Pennsylvania, clothing worn by survivors, and objects used by rescue workers and public officials. The collection also includes several everyday items that have now taken on extraordinary significance because of their association with the Sept. 11 events.

What will you see?

  • Sony DSR-PD150 digital camcorder used by Jules Naudet on September 11, 2001

  • Airplane fragments found in the wreckage of the World Trade Center

  • Door from a New York fire truck crushed in the collapse of the World Trade Center (or A FDNY truck door)

  • Crushed file cabinet recovered from the rubble of the World Trade Center

  • Section of a steel column from an upper floor of one of the World Trade Center towers, twisted by the force of the 110-story building‚Äôs collapse

  • Desk telephone on which Ted Olson received calls from his wife, Barbara Olson, a passenger on Flight 77

  • Teddy bear, softball, and sign made by flight attendants ‚Äîmemorial offerings left near the Flight 93 crash site in Somerset County, Pennsylvania

  • Bunker coat and helmet worn by FDNY Battalion Chief Joseph Pfeifer, the first fire chief to arrive at the World Trade Center on September 11

  • Rescue tool recovered with the body of Lt. Kevin J. Pfeifer, a New York City firefighter killed in the collapse of the World Trade Center

  • Squeegee handle used by Jan Demczur and five other men to escape from a World Trade Center elevator on September 11

  • Elevator emergency-instruction panel, World Trade Center

  • Elevator floor-number plates, World Trade Center

  • Shoes worn on September 11 by Maria Cecilia Benavente; she removed them to speed her exit from the 103rd floor of the south tower

  • Stairwell sign from the 102nd floor, World Trade Center

There a few photos of items on the high resolution image page¬†and if you have extra time they are also looking for volunteers to help out.¬†The Museum of History is located in Tacoma, Washington.

item.title: Announcing the Getting Things Done Wiki ‚Äì We need your help
item.description:
I‚Äôve been doing the Getting Things Done (GTD) for the last few years. I‚Äôve read the book, listened to the cds and have attended David‚Äôs three day class. GTD has helped me stay sane and manage the volumes of information I get each day. Last week David came and spoke to our organization at Microsoft.

Even though I‚Äôve attended David‚Äôs seminar and consider myself on my way to be a GTD blackbelt üôÇ I still picked up a number of tips and continue to refine how I use the system.

One of the challenges is collecting all the information on Getting Things Done that is out there. Its scattered amongst weblog posts and David‚Äôs awesome site¬†that has many helpful documents. So a group of us we‚Äôre talking internally (actually David Weller came up with the idea) about setting up an internal Wiki to help track Getting Things Done links.

A GTD wiki would be a great resource, but it would be a shame to put it behind the Microsoft firewall limiting access to just Microsoft Employees, so we all decided that an external one would be the best. So I‚Äôve created a section on my Flexwiki for Getting Things Done Topics.¬†You can find it at http://wiki.jeffsandquist.com/default.aspx/GTD/HomePage.html¬†there‚Äôs a simple link to it from http://wiki.jeffsandquist.com

Help us build an encyclopedia of Getting Things Done, tips, tools and more! Lets let a thousand flowers bloom.

item.title: Josie and her hip
item.description:
This past week we got some good news regarding Josie and her hip‚Ä¶

When we last left you the advice we had gotten from the surgeon was that, ‚ÄúIt may or not get better in the next couple of years, we‚Äôll have to wait and see‚Äù.¬† We took this advice back to Josie‚Äôs primary physician and he was dissapointed, actually visibly troubled. He couldn‚Äôt believe no X-Rays were taken or that certain specific tests weren‚Äôt completed. He set up another referral with a different physician this time at Swedish Medical Center.

The Doctor we were referred to was much more thorough and took x-rays this time of Josie and the good news is all is well. Josie does have a ‚Äútoe in dysplasia‚Äù. Many years ago they might have put a brace on her, that we now know would not do a thing to fix her ailment and probably would do more damage mentally. They don‚Äôt do that anymore.

We learnt that a number of athletes have this time of dysplasia. One example is John Elway. He has this same ‚Äútoe in‚Äù problem and it makes him a super fast runner. ¬†(Or so says this third Doctor from Denver :-))

So thank you all for your kind comments on my previous post and your private e-mails. When I wrote my feelings publicly, I did so as a bit of therapy. I was blown away by all the kind words from you all and the number of referrers from Google possible from parents looking for information on their own kids. item.title: Los Angeles Convention Center ‚Äì Get your data/network/internet and plumbing services
item.description:
As Steve mentions we went on a site visit to the LA Convention Center last Thursday. It was a whirlwind trip, we flew in Thursday morning arriving at LAX around noon, spent about 4 hours at the convention center and flew back home the same day.

This will be the forth PDC that I‚Äôve worked on. The first PDC that I worked on (in Denver) was working a booth for the Sitebuilder Network. The last three PDCs have been driven out of my immediate time so I‚Äôve been ‚Äúcloser to the fire‚Äù as they say. Again this year I‚Äôll be driving the community stuff for the event both our online and offline activities.

Getting down to the convention center and performing the walk through brought back great memories of PDC 2003. What an amazing ride that was‚Ä¶

We‚Äôve got a lot of work as a team ahead of us, we‚Äôre in the ultra early stages. Lots of planning meetings, brainstorming and¬†sync up meetings.¬†On community we‚Äôve started to put a few things down on paper and once we get out of blue sky mode I hope to be able to share some of the ideas and get your feedback through this weblog. I can‚Äôt share everything though, if I did that then there wouldn‚Äôt be the pleasant surprises üôÇ

The site visit was great. It is quite different walking through a venue as large as the LA Convention Center with no people around. We use the walk through to get an idea of how the space will be used. Often there are additional rooms available that may not have been open in previous years. That opens up options for using the space for breakouts or community activiities.

You also get a feel for the of scale of things. Many of the spaces like the Expo hall are drawn out on a CAD system for us to understand furniture placement. Even though I did a fair amount of drafting in college their is no substitute for comparing the drawing to the real thing.

So on last Thursday‚Äôs trip we walked the convention center, met with the convention center staff, took a tonne of notes and took many pictures.

As we get closer to the event you‚Äôll hear more folks who are part of the ‚ÄúPDC all volunteer army‚Äù blogging as well.

We‚Äôll try and keep you in the loop on what goes¬†on pulling an event like this.

Cheers!

P.S. I‚Äôve posted this weblog entry under a category called ‚ÄúPDC‚Äù. I‚Äôve also posted the photos on this entry into Flickr.com with the a category of PDC as well. If I understand Technorati‚Äôs new TAG functionality correctly, then this entry along with my photos from Flickr should all show up on the technorati TAG page for PDC which is located at PDC

item.title: Having a family is like having your heart walk around outside your body
item.description:
‚ÄúHaving a family is a lot like have your heart walk around outside your body‚Äù

For the last 36 hours we‚Äôve been through a bit of turmoil in our little family.¬†

For those of you who know me or those who don‚Äôt but follow¬†my blog, I talk endless about Josie¬†our 5¬†year old little girl.¬†My wife¬†sums¬†up Josie‚Äôs personality with the following sentence, ‚ÄúJosie is Jeff in a dress!‚Äù. Now don‚Äôt get me wrong, Josie is all girl. She loves princesses, plays with Barbies and of course ballet. She can tell a good Joke (ask her about Bob the duck). She has another side though that is rough and tough. She‚Äôll make ramps for her bike, loves to run room to room and of course setting up pillows on the couch in order to maximum air. For play things in the backyard she has a BMX bike, hockey sticks and a baseball too!

Over the Christmas break my wife and I noticed that Josie walks with one of her feet twisted in. Quite substantially acutally, her left foot is¬†turned about 60 degrees inward as she walks or when she runs. We kept a pretty good eye on this for a number of days and it persisted. I figured it couldn‚Äôt be¬†that big of a deal, but we decided to make an appointment with our Orthopedist. The appointment was supposed to be last week, but on the day of the appointment we were hit with frozen rain. To be safe Lauri rescheduled it to this week. Our home is up on a hill in Sammamish and when freezing rain hits you don‚Äôt want to be away as you just might be spending the night in a hotel in Redmond. üôÇ This was the right choice.

Yesterday I was in back to back meetings all day, so Lauri took Josie to the Doctor by herself. Through the afternoon my mobile phone rings a few times and I let it go to voicemail, I also notice in my inbox I have a number of voicemails. I don‚Äôt think much of it. With being in back to back meetings I wasn‚Äôt able to check them, all I know is that they are from my wife as it has her numbers in the call display.

Around 5:00 pm I‚Äôm able to connect with my wife and I can tell immediately something is wrong by the tone of her voice. Lauri, starts off calmy saying that, ‚ÄúOur Doctor says we need to get¬†Josie into an Orthopedic Surgeon right away‚Äù, by the end of the sentence tears are taking over her words. I pack up and head home.

Prior to moving to the United States, I lived in Canada. On the prairies the nearest specialist was at least 3 hours away and you‚Äôd need to book it 90 days in advance. My mind raced with what could be so urgent in that our appointment with a surgeon is less than 24 hours from now. I get home with probably one of the longest 30 minute commutes I‚Äôve ever had. I eventually get home and my wife explains what went down at the Doctor‚Äôs appointment.

The Doctor completed a number of range of motion tests with Josie and was quite surprised to hear that we hadn‚Äôt been advised of Josie‚Äôs hip problems. The Doctor was quite concerned that Josie does not have complete motion of her left hip.¬† In fact in comparison to her right she has a substantial lack of motion. There was a good chance that a series of braces might be required or even surgery. My heart sunk, I hugged my wife and held Josie probably as a close as I ever have and said I silent prayer. We don‚Äôt have much for family here (well actiually we have none), Lauri is my best friend, so it wasn‚Äôt like we had friends around our family to talk. We took it easy, played Uno with Josie, read her a few stories and tried to get to bed early.¬†Josie had an appointment at 8:00 with a surgeon in Bellevue and in order to get us all there in time we‚Äôd be up at 6:00 am. This all seemed so surreal.

So we went to sleep,¬†meanwhile I‚Äôm fighting a nasty head cold and Lauri and I both ended up tossing¬†and turning most of the night. I‚Äôd try and remind myself¬†in the scheme of things that this couldn‚Äôt be that big of a¬†deal could this be? It couldn‚Äôt be cancer, that makes no sense. Then¬†of course my mind races to my¬†Dad who 6 years ago was given only 6 months to live¬†(he‚Äôs still going strong Today) and my¬†father-in-law who lost the battle¬†to cancer almost 7 years ago. I shake that thought away. You know a¬†tired¬†body, stress and bedtime just don‚Äôt mix. It makes you think crazy things. I eventually fall to sleep around 3 am and by 6 am I decide to just get out of bed as sleep is just not working. I notice Lauri has already gotten up out of bed already. She didn‚Äôt sleep much either. I‚Äôm exhausted and just want this day to end (the night before I only got about 4 hours sleep as well as I had tossed and turned with my head cold, but that is another story).

I wake Josie up around 6:45 and she just wants to roll over and go back to bed, but we get her dressed and she‚Äôs excited that I‚Äôm going to go to the Doctor with her, we head out the door, I follow her and Lauri off to the Doctor. As we drive along Lake Sammamish and the sun is rising I see her waving back at me from Lauri‚Äôs rear window.

We get to the Doctor‚Äôs office, we‚Äôre the only ones there. Josie and I practice letters and numbers in one of her coloring books while mom fills out insurance records and registration data. In no time at all we see the Doctor. He repeats the range of motion tests and notices the problems that the Orthopedic doctor did. He has Josie walk down the hall and later run and he and another Doctor in the hall comment on how her left foot is substantially turned in. My heart drops.

We return to his office and I wonder what‚Äôs next‚Ä¶. He goes on to tell us that this could be something or could be nothing. We need watch it closely for the next year to see if she grows out of it. Many years ago they would immediately strap a brace on the child, but often found that it did nothing. He did not want to do an X-Ray as they didn‚Äôt want to inundate Josie with the radiation.

So we sit here tonight, tired and grateful that we didn‚Äôt get worse news. On one hand I‚Äôm left wondering, should we get a second opinion or should we just wait and see. We‚Äôve got¬†a follow up appointment with her Doctor to discuss more.

To be honest I am thankful that we‚Äôre dealing with something that is not a debilitating disease. This is not cancer and I could never imagine how parents make it through that kind of thing with their childrenI can say is that. All I can say is children are a like have your heart walk around outside your body.

item.title: Forcing Windows XP to Restart after connecting via a remote desktop connection
item.description:
My Windows XP Media Center is located in an entertainment center and hidden away from view. It runs 99 per cent of the time with the 10‚Äô User Experience that I control via my remote control. In order to ensure that machine is always running in the 10‚Äô User Experience it is configured to automatically logon using the Windows XP Tweak UI Power Toy¬†upon boot. This works well, but if I connect to the mahine via a remote desktop connection and then logoff, it leaves the computer with a Windows XP logon dialog. ¬†

I ended up doing the following:

  1. Downloaded PsShutdown from Sysinternals which allows me to initiate a shutdown and restart
  2. Ran Group Policy Editor (Start -> Run -> gpedit.msc)
  3. In Group Policy Editor went to User Configuration -> Windows Settings -> Scripts (Logon/Logoff) and selected Logoff
  4. Pointed the LogOff Script to psshutdown.exe -r -t 10

Now whenever I log off of the Media Center PC it forces a reboot ensuring that the machine is always running in the correct state and ready for use. If anyone has a better way I‚Äôm all ears. üòâ

Postscript: J.P. Stewart¬†asks in my comments , why didn‚Äôt I just restart the ehome shell upon logoff instead of forcing a restart of XP? The problem is that upon connection to the media center via remote desktop, Windows XP securely locks the local connection¬†displaying the Windows XP logon screen on the Television set. I need to restart the machine in order to login, leaving my media center machine in wife acceptance mode. üôÇ

item.title: Skype 1.1 Setup Just Hangs
item.description:
Has anyone gotten Skype 1.1 to install? I‚Äôm building out this laptop while writing a tutorial on how to Podcast on XP and Skype setup won‚Äôt run. The process just hangs. It looks like other users are encountering the same problem.

Any suggestions?

Postscript: Omar came up with a solution in my comments that worked. To install Skype 1.1 I had to boot XP into safe mode (without networking support) Here are the steps you need to take:

1. Download Skype 1.1 to your local machine
2. Reboot Windows XP and hold down F8 to get the boot menu
3. Select Safe mode without networking support (I tried with Networking and it still failed)
4. Log onto XP with your administrator account
5. Run Skype setup

Result? Joy! Skype 1.1 will install. Thanks Omar.

item.title: Getting Things Done This New Year
item.description:
I swear by the Getting Things Done system and wrote a two part primer a few months back, the system was life changing for me.¬† I get at least one or two people weekly asking me about the system and on how to get started, so by writing this up in my blog, I now have a reference for them on how to get started.

Here are my posts:

How I get things done / Kicking some butt on your email inbox ‚Äì Part 1
How I get things done / Kicking some butt on your email inbox ‚Äì Part 2

Now, Merlin at 43 Folders has now also written a three part article marking his 1 year anniversary of Getting Things Done. They are great posts!

A Year of Getting Things Done: Part 1, The Good Stuff
A Year of Getting Things Done: Part 2, The Stuff I Wish I Were Better At
A Year of Getting Things Done: Part 3, The Future of GTD?

Once you adopt the system and if you use Outlook, you‚Äôll find that¬†tasks is your most important view from Outlook. If you use the GTD Outlook Add-In (which I strongly recommend) you might want to also paste in the GTD Police Macro that I found recently on the Getting Things Done Add-In Support Forum.

With the Getting Things Done Add-In, you will find yourself driving completion of projects by creating new Outlook tasks and asking yourself, ‚ÄúWhat is the next action that I need to take this project forward?‚Äù. The Task is assigned to a project. It can be a bit of a pain creating new tasks whenever you complete a task for a project,¬†¬†as most projects take more than one step to complete.¬†

The GTD Police Macro simplifies it all by monitoring your tasks folder and when you complete a task that is associated with a project, a dialog box opens asking you whether you want to create a new Next Action for the project. Answering yes causes a task form to open and automatically assigned to the project.

The last resource I give you for the new year is Sylvia‚Äôs Getting Things Done Resource Page¬†where you‚Äôll find diagrams¬†and links. Office Zealot has an awesome GTD section as well with links to articles and blogs!

Big thanks to Lenn Pryor who¬†a couple of years back¬†let me know about Getting Things Done. It changed my life, let me know if you adopt the practice.¬†

item.title: More ballots than voters
item.description:
I had mentioned previously that I looked forward to Dino Rossi possibly taking on Maria Cantwell in ‚Äò06. With some of the recent discoveries I don‚Äôt expect Dino to concede any time soon now.

Check out the following from Sound Politics:

It was last reported that there were 3,539 more ballots counted in King County than voters who cast them. The discrepancy is actually much larger. The 3,539 is only the net. item.title: Excel Inspiration?
item.description:
Digging through my referrer log after reading Julie Leung‚Äôs unexpected gifts amongst garbage post, I found an unexpected post from Dennis E. Hamilton talking about his recent weight loss¬†and how he employed a meal tracking spreadsheet like the one I use.

But then Jeff Sandquist inspired me by his description of his 20-20 program.¬† I followed his blog posts from the beginning, but it was when he first showed his spreadsheet that it dawned on me.¬† I know how to keep track and use spread sheets to monitor diet programs.¬† I haven‚Äôt been doing that and I have never counted calories.

I am thrilled it is working for you Dennis, it sure has for me as I am now down to 158 pounds. That is just 3 pounds from my goal of 155. They talk about the importance of meal tracking continuously in 20/20 and say that folks that keep the weight off, continue with meal tracking. I am definitely a believer, it helps you understand the choices you make.

I try and keep my daily calorie range somewhere from 1500 to 1650 calories and my total fat at 33‚Äì55 grams. I‚Äôve found that when my caloric intake is high I lose more weight. My dietician tells me that its because my metabolism slows down when I am low on calories. So much for thinking eating less will cause you to lose weight üôÇ Before the program 1500‚Äì1600 calories might have been the total for one trip to a fast food restaurant, but it seems like a lot to me now. I don‚Äôt fixate on the daily total for calories, sure I try and keep them in range, but what I do is total up the average for the past week and look at how I did on average.

My current work out schedule includes approximately five 3 mile runs per week over some pretty nasty inclines that we have up here on the Sammamish Plateau. Lauri and I got a great deal on a baby jogger from the want ads at work and now

Josie can come along for the ride too. She call‚Äôs it¬†the¬†‚ÄúJosie Jogger‚Äù as she‚Äôs¬†no longer a baby, she‚Äôs five! Aside from the cardio I also do 3 weight lifting sessions per week at the Pro Club¬†trying to get some tone now that the flab has gone away.

It‚Äôs been a lot of fun to get to this point and I certainly don‚Äôt feel like I‚Äôm missing anything food wise. Next I‚Äôll write about some of my new favorite recipes.

Cheers!

item.title: I prefer the XDA III over the AudioVox

item.title: PDC'05 ‚Äì We've got the band back together
item.description:
Steve (my boss ;-)) talks about how he found out about his role as content owner for the last PDC from Vic our General Manager:

Vic Gundotra,¬†walked in my office and in a manner one might use to, say, borrow a spare power adapter told me that he‚Äôd volunteered me to be content owner for PDC‚Äô03. Given that the PDC has always been run out of his org, ‚Äúassigned‚Äù is probably a better word than ‚Äúvolunteered‚Äù, but Vic is a gracious guy and he used ‚Äúvolunteered‚Äù.

Funny thing happened to me about that same time. I was in a 1:1 with Vic, finishing up a review on a project. At the end of the meeting Vic said something like this, ‚ÄúHey Jeff.. I‚Äôve got something really fun for you. I want you to go down to Steve‚Äôs office and let him know that whatever he needs an extra hand with for the PDC you‚Äôre his man.‚Äù

Through my life at Microsoft I‚Äôve dreamt of being a part of the great history of events before us so I jumped at the opportunity and went down and saw Steve.

Steve, responded with a bit of a surprise and said something like, ‚ÄúGreat. I guess I‚Äôll need some help‚Äù. Two weeks ago I completed phase one of the 20/20 program¬†at the Pro Club. It‚Äôs been a complete tranformation for me and I‚Äôm excited to move onto the next phase which is all about keeping the weight off. Curious what this is all about? Check out my previous posts about the program:

What did I learn?
Lots, but my top 4 take aways were:

  1. Always wear a heart rate monitor when working out. I believe that in the past I never truly worked out, I never broke a sweat, this was because I never worked hard enough.
  2. Get proper shoes for running. I was running in cross¬†training shoes and it hurt. It wasn‚Äôt until I got properly fitted at the Foot Zone in Redmond Town Center was I able to get running.
  3. Eating less doesn‚Äôt mean you‚Äôll lose weight. In fact you might lose less. I found I had my best weight loss when I kept my calories at the 1500‚Äì1600 range.
  4. Meal tracking is critical, its¬†the only way I can make sure I get the right amount of fat and calories in¬†for my day.

So what next?
I now meet with my trainer twice a week (instead of three times) and my dietician goes to a bi-weekly schedule from weekly. This lasts for 12 weeks. I still work out 5¬†days a week but my trainer appointmnets are now focussed on weight training. I still want to drop approximately 3¬†pounds to bring myself to my ideal body weight.

The program has transformed our¬†family life.¬†We no longer eat fast food, in fact the idea of¬†eating disgusts me.¬†For fun¬†my wife and I enjoy running together¬†which is something I‚Äôve never imagined doing or enjoying as much as I do. item.title: The MSN Deskbar is a hidden gem in the new MSN Search
item.description:
The MSN Deskbar is a hidden gem in the new desktop search which the MSN team [shipped in beta form today][1]. From the [help page][2]: 

With MSN Deskbar, you can create shortcuts that let you quickly start programs, open documents, or go directly to a website, just by typing a keyword in the Deskbar search box. For example, you could create a shortcut that automatically opens the Hotmail home page when you type hotmail into the Deskbar search box.

Some examples of queries you can create (what cool ones can you come up with?)‚Ä¶

To create a shortcut that Enter this in the Deskbar search box
Opens a website (for example, www.hotmail.com) when you type hotmail @shortcutname,webaddress

For example, @hotmail,www.hotmail.com

Be sure not to include any spaces after the comma.

Performs a query on a Web page when you type (shortcut name) (search term)

For example, quote msft for a stock quote, or encarta einstein for encyclopedia articles about Einstein.

@shortcutname,webaddress$w

For example:

@quote,http://moneycentral.msn.com/scripts/webquote.dll?iPage=qd&Symbol=$w.

@encarta,http://encarta.msn.com/encnet/refpages/search.aspx?q=$w

Tip: Try performing a search on a website such as encarta.msn.com. When you see your search results page, your search terms should be included at the end of the web address in the Internet Explorer address bar. Copy the web address but replace your search terms with $w. Use this new web address to create your shortcut.

Opens a document (for example, resume.doc) when you type resume @shortcutname,c:\(document path)\(document name)

For example, @resume,C:\resume.doc.

Be sure not to include any spaces after the comma.

Opens a program (for example, Notepad) when you type note @shortcutname,=[program command]

For example, @note,=notepad.exe

Be sure not to include any spaces after the comma

item.title: Switching Mobile Phone Carriers and Keeping Your Phone Number Works
item.description:
I changed from Cingular to T-Mobile this last week and kept my phone number. It was easy and it worked!

Here‚Äôs all I had to do:

  1. Let my service contract for Cingular end so I could move on.
  2. I called T-Mobile and told them my Cingular phone number and Cingular Account Number
  3. T-Mobile sent me a new SIM chip (I have an XDA II phone that is unlocked so all I needed was the chip)
  4. Replaced the Cingular SIM chip in my phone with T-Mobile and it worked with my original phone number.
  5. Changed my GPRS settings to point to T-Mobile‚Äôs settings.

I did call Cingular today just to confirm that I was removed from their system and the customer representative confirmed that I was no longer a customer.

I moved from Cingular to T-Mobile because Cingular does not have an all you can eat data plan.

item.title: I've turned off my Tivo
item.description:
I‚Äôve turned off my Tivo,¬†I no longer need it.¬†

Its been a great product that I‚Äôve evangelized to friends, family and co-workers. I no longer need it though as I‚Äôve replaced it with a new PVR that Comcast just brought onto the market.

It is a great unit and my the wife acceptance factor was high. (she‚Äôs using it now and totally gets how to use it).

You can watch a video here¬†of the user experience or geek out on the AVSForum for more detailed information.

What I love most is that it has dual tuners. I can record one program while I watch another or even record two programs at the same time. This is something I‚Äôve always wanted to do with my Tivo but it was only available if I got a DirectTivo and a Satellite dish. I don‚Äôt want a dish out the front of my home.

I love the fact that it supports recording of HDTV, this is somethign that Tivo hasn‚Äôt announced plans on yet for cable. I believe they‚Äôve got an HDTV box for Direct TV, but I think its in the $1000 range. Added bonus no more delay delay while changing channels. The Tivo had a minor interruption while changing channels as it had to send a blast of infrared to the cable box. Now with an integrated unit in the cable box I don‚Äôt have to deal with that.

I know I can‚Äôt hack the unit, or show pictures or play music with it, but this is a nice unit and I can put my Tivos on eBay.¬†For my power user scenarios I‚Äôve got a Windows Media Center PC running upstairs in our bedroom.

Congratulations Comcast and the folks on the Media Foundation Team¬†on a great product.

Thanks Tivo for teaching me about how a PVR will change your life and give me control over my TV. I look forward to a future of possibilities with Media Center and Media Foundation!

item.title: Spinning at the Pro Club ‚Äî I did it
item.description:
Friday (yesterday) marked the beginning of week 6 for me and the 20/20 Program at the Pro Sports Club. I‚Äôm now down to 172 pounds and have been losing weight at the rate of 2 to 3 pounds per week. I did lose about 10¬†pounds before actually beginning the program.

Yesterday, was a breakthrough day. I participated in a Spinning Class with my trainer. Spinning is something I have always wanted to try and had hoped to do by the end of the program. I used to race BMX as a teen and want biking to be a part of my life again. Imagine my surprise when my trainer said I was ready to do the class now. To prepare we gradually increased my cardio workout until I could ‚Äúcomfortably‚Äù get 45 minutes in. We started using the exercise bike more than the ellypticals or the treadmill. This was to simulate what the class would be like so I could have an idea.

So on to Friday the big day. My trainer and I met at our regular time and did some upper body lifting. We then went to the class about 10 minutes early so we could get my bike setup. I met the instructer (Drill Seargant?) who‚Äôs name was Buzz. Buzz helped me set the bike up.¬†You can see by the picture to the right that is a very industrial looking thing. The key part is the flywheel which means¬†that when pedaling you have the sensation of riding a¬†real bike. One important thing is once you get rolling fast you need to use the break to stop. Just stopping pedaling does¬†nothing and could be painful.

We finished getting my bike adjusted and my trainer wrote down the settings on my punch card. This way I would know how to setup my bike for the next spinning class I attend. I thought to myself, ‚ÄúNext class? Wow that‚Äôs wishful thinking lets just see if I can make it through half of this this hour long class!‚Äù

The class began to fill, folks of all shapes and sizes arrived and got their bikes configured. My trainer and I began to warm up a bet, just doing some light pedaling. I really liked the feel of the bike. Pedaling felt ‚Äúreal‚Äù compared to the artificial tension of the traditional exercise bikes.

The instructor (Buzz) mounted his bike that was on a riser at the front of the room. He donned at headset microphone, dimmed the lights and welcomed folks to the class. Cranking up the music he began to talk us through some light stretching exercises.

We began to spin to N-Trance‚Äôs Remix of Staying Alive.¬†I thought to myself how cool is this!¬†We warmed up. Buzz‚Äôs voice reminded me of embarking on a roller coaster ride as a teenager and listening to the ride operator saying, ‚ÄúKeep your hands inside the car at all time‚Äù. Instead this was Buzz and his voice was saying things like..

‚ÄúIf your feet pull out of the pedals make sure you pull the break‚Äù

‚ÄúIf you run out of water raise your hand and I‚Äôll refill your water bottel‚Äù

‚ÄúPush yourself hard, crank your tension up, if its to hard you can always turn it down‚Äù.

Buzz went on to explain the levels he‚Äôd ask us to do. For example if he asked for a level 6 that means we should be able to keep the pace up for 20 minutes. A level 7 would mean 15 minutes and so on. He then asked for a level 7 on a flat road. I adjusted my tension more and figured ok, we‚Äôre on our way! We continued on the imaginary flat road I was enjoying the bass reverberating and hardly believing that I was actually doing this.

The class was amazing. By turning up the tension on the bike we simulated hill climbing, we did jumps by rising on and off the seat and flat roads where we cooled down. I was soaken wet with sweat, my heart rate range was from 150-165 but most importantly I was having a blast!

The music in our class reminded me a lot of C895.5 FM. Remixes and dance, all great music. I watched the clock, wondering to myself could I make the whole hour?

I pushed and pushed. I worked harder than I ever had since starting 20/20. Working out in a group session is motivating. People really got into the class. When the music was pumping and we were pushing hard folks would yell out a congralatory yah! when we‚Äôd complete the rise to the top of another incline.

Before I knew it we were winding down to an instrumental version of Send in the clowns. We did some light stretching and before I knew it, it was over. I was tired, soaken wet with sweat, but I did it! I made it through the class, my legs were tired, but not mush.

Buzz came over and high fived me as did my trainer. They both asked, ‚ÄúWhen will you be back?‚Äù My reply? ‚ÄúNext Friday!‚Äù

item.title: Tracking 20/20 Progress with Excel
item.description:
Today marks the beginning of week 5 for me and the 20/20 program. An amazing change is taking place in my life.

When I first started the program my trainer had the tension level on the ellipticals set to 3 and this was the most I could do. My heart rate would quickly rise to over 160 and I‚Äôd tire out quickly.

Last night was quite a different story, we had the tension level set to 8 and my heart rate was at 155. Up until 20/20 I never wore a heart rate monitor. Makes me wonder if I truly ever worked out. I don‚Äôt think I ever got my heart rate up nonetheless. Its so cool to see my endurance building up. I‚Äôve had some problems with my left knee, specifically joint pain, so I haven‚Äôt been able to job like I had dreamed. I still have hopes of doing that, so we‚Äôre working on strengthening my legs and hopefully that will come soon.

So how am I doing? My energy is at an all time high. I can‚Äôt remember ever being so focussed. Getting my diet into control eliminates my highs and lows during the day. The weight is coming off too. Last July I was over 200 pounds and as of today I am weighing in at 176.

My goal is to get to 160 pounds with dropping about 2 pounds a week. To keep track of progress I am tracking my weight loss in Excel along with my daily eating habits. Here‚Äôs a screenshot of how I am doing it:

The blue line shows my actual weight loss and the pink line shows the ideal loss rate of 2 pounds per week. By losing 2 pounds a week I‚Äôm not crash dieting. It is the healthy way of doing it.

As far as diet goes, I‚Äôve expanded past the shakes and now have 4 servings of vegetables each day (1/2 cup of green peppers equals a serving) and also yogurt. I‚Äôm trying to keep my calories at 1550.

Would you believe that in less than a week I‚Äôll be going into my first spinning class? My trainer says I am ready, I‚Äôll let you know how it goes.

This feels great.

item.title: Precisely Counting Calories and Yeh Baby I'mlosing weight!
item.description:
Yesterday I started week 3 of the 20/20 program. I decided to start the program¬†about 6 weeks ago in August. That‚Äôs when I filled out the paperwork, got the medical tests done and was weighing in at 201 pounds.

As of yesterday I am now at 185 pounds and feeling great! That is an eighteen pound drop in weight and am continue to lose it at an average of 2.9 pounds per week. My goal is to get to 161 pounds.

To be clear I started watching what I eat about 6 weeks back, well before 20/20 started. I did some basic things like:

  • eliminating soda pop
    • cut out high end coffees and espresso (I still have one 8 oz. drip of black coffee each day)
      • increased my water intake to 64 ounces per day

        • cut out candy, donuts, bagels and bread

          • slowing down when I eat
          My goal was to drop weight before starting the program and to elimate as much sugar and caffeine ahead of time as I could. I was worried that the baselining phase would be to hard and that the headaches would affect my day job, so I thought tapering down ahead of time might help.

        This seemed to work, I did feel like I was hitting the ground running with my training. I still had terrible headaches in the first 3 days most likely from sugar withdrawl. It is amazing how much sugar is in all the things we eat.On the other I hand once I got through that I felt great. In fact I can‚Äôt remember when I‚Äôve felt better. The working out has been the perfect compliment to starting my new job.

        One of the big lessons I‚Äôve learned so far is the importance of precisely watching my calories. Right now I am trying to keep my calories in the 1600 to 1700 range. In order to do that I track ever calorie and every gram of fat in a meal tracker.

        I was using a checkbook style book to write them in but it was a pain to sum the columns and sub-food times so I ended up devising a very simply Excel spreadsheet to track my food intake. I‚Äôve included a sample of a typical day below. (PB = 1 TBSP of Organic Peanut Butter)

        I track the meal, what I ate, the calories, fat and any comments. I also keep track of what my exercise was that day. It is really important to track any cravings or if you are hungry too. I review this data with my dietition weekly and we adjust accordingly. For example the previous week I was often craving peanuts and mushrooms in butter. Based on that we doubled my fat intake this week and my cravings have all gone away.

        Calorie counting is pretty interesting, one of my favorite foods of past was the A&W‚Äôs Bacon Double Cheeseburger¬†(837 calories) and of course on the side of onion rings (353 calories) for a total of 1190 calories.¬†Thats pretty close to what I am eating all day now. I‚Äôve got a book version of the calorie king web site and its fun to go and look at all the things I used to eat and see how many calories they are like the Awesome Blossom from Chili‚Äôs which is 2880 calories.

        I think I am making this sound effortless, it hasn‚Äôt. I have such a long weigh to go and its hard not to cheat. I haven‚Äôt yet, but am sure I will and wonder how I‚Äôll make it through Halloween, Thanks Giving and Christmas, but I am on my way. I am really sore too from all the working out. In fact in my Friday training session we had to move off of the treadmill to a bicycle for my cardio because my joints were so sore, possibly from jogging the night before.

        Inch by inch!

item.title: I broke my iPod
item.description:
Dang it. I was loading up my gym bag last night and my iPod fell to the floor. It landed with a thud on the hardwood floors in my kitchen with a large thud. I packed in my bag thinking that it would be fine. It wasn‚Äôt all right, its dead. Its now a great paper weight just displaying a folder with an explanation mark on it. üôÅ

So am I off to the Apple store to replace it with a new one? Nope. No thanks.

I am going to replace it with something listed on the Playsforsure.com web site or some other cool new device.

Why?

  1. I don‚Äôt need an iPod to listen to Podcasts. Phil has great instructions on how to get it to a Portable Media Center so I won‚Äôt be missing the latest trend by not picking an iPod and the other iPodders are supporting Windows Media Player.

  2. I want DRM music.

Wait.. What, isn‚Äôt this evil? Am I nuts (waiting for the Slashdot ant-drm kids to fall down on me). Nope, just a family guy on a budget. I don‚Äôt want to pay 99 cents per song, but want to pay the artists for music I use. (read: I don‚Äôt want to steal music)

DRM gives me a way to do that. I am working out a lot. I want lots of different music for working out. I don‚Äôt want to pay 99 cents for every song I move to my device. I‚Äôd rather just pay for a Naspter monthly subscription at $9.99 per month be able to download most of the songs to my device when I take off to the gym. I can try songs out, move them to my device, remove them, add more and listen to lots of songs. I don‚Äôt think the entire library is available this way (some I‚Äôll have to pay 99 cents for) but this is way cheaper and a more open experience in my mind.

So help me find the right device. I want something that won‚Äôt quit working when it drops to the floor like my iPod did.

¬†

IPodder ‚Äì The process of getting Podcasts out of the feed and onto your portable music device
