item.title: How I get things done / Kicking some butt on your email inbox ‚Äì Part 2
item.description:
This is part 2 of my series on getting a handle on your email inbox. In part 1, I talked discussed David Allen‚Äôs Getting Things Done Methodology. I can‚Äôt emphasize his approach enough, he has help me and many friends clear our phsycic ram and get things done.

In this part I won‚Äôt focus as much on Getting Things Done, but on explaining how I use Outlook Rules, Folder Heirarchy and Custom Folders Views to manage projects and eliminate inbox hell. Hopefully we can get you out of inbox hell with this and on the road to a single digit inbox. This is all based on lessons I‚Äôve learnt managing my mail while working at Microsoft for¬†the last 7 years. (We get a lot of email here :-)).

**Outlook Rules
** I always say, ‚ÄúSet too few outlook rules and you‚Äôre inbox is swimming, set too many rules and you‚Äôll miss key mails or respond slowly.‚Äù Be careful with rules, never set them on indidivual people.

I always set rules at the mailing/distribution list level. For example, I‚Äôll never set a rule to move mails sent to me from Robert Scoble to a special folder, but I will have mail sent to a distribution list like Steve Cellini‚Äôs Team moved to a folder of its own.

I always tell folks when helping them get out of Inbox hell, your inbox is for mails that you are on the to: or cc: lines, thats it! By only having mail in your inbox with your name on the to: or cc: line you know right away that it is mail that an action needs to be dealt with.

So what about the mail that is sent to a distribtution list and has been moved to a folder?

By having emails sent to distribution lists moved to folders, you can group together conversations of the same context in a folder. It also helps you set priority of reading mail. There are social and technical discussion lists that I am on that may be interesting, but something I often can‚Äôt read during the day. So I‚Äôve got technical discussions about the Tablet PC Development all in one folder and the Canucks at Microsoft grouped together in another.

When the folders turn bold in the Outlook folder view I know there are new mails and can decide if I should read them now or defer until later. Also because all the replies are grouped closely together and not scattered amongst mail sent direct to me in my inbox, I can quickly jump to the latest response and read the whole thread. Nothing is more embaressing than jumping on an email and replying when the answer was given hours before.

So how do I create rules quickly? Outlook makes it a snap with the Create Rule icon in the toolbar.

The create rule button pops up a dialog populated with who the mail was sent to. I can quickly create a rule based on this message and after you filling in the blanks I can run it against my inbox. Perfect for those surprise distribution lists you all of a sudden become a member of without knowing üòâ

While working your way out of inbox hell, you can use this option to buzz through the mails in your inbox creating rules based on what broad distribution list the mail set to and select the option to run against your inbox now. Before you know it you‚Äôll be out of inbox hell.

**Folder Heirarchy
** The biggest mistake I often see folks make is they often go way to deep with their Outlook folder heirarchy, here‚Äôs my Outlook folder layout.

Inbox
¬† @Accepted Meeting Requests
¬† @Action
¬† @Autogroup
¬† @Deferred
¬† @Projects
¬†¬†@Waiting For
¬† @Weblog Referrals
¬† Distributions Lists
¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†Biz ‚Äì¬†Some¬†Distribution¬†or mailing list
¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†Biz ‚Äì¬†Some¬†Distribution¬†or mailing list
¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†Biz ‚Äì¬†Some¬†Distribution¬†or mailing list
¬†¬†¬†¬† Dog ‚Äì¬†Some¬†Distribution¬†or mailing list
¬†¬†¬†¬† Dog ‚Äì¬†Some¬†Distribution¬†or mailing list
¬†¬†¬†¬† Dog ‚Äì¬†Some¬†Distribution¬†or mailing list
¬†¬†¬†¬† Dog ‚Äì¬†Some¬†Distribution¬†or mailing list
¬†¬†¬†¬† Soc¬†‚Äì Some¬†Distribution¬†or mailing list
¬†¬†¬†¬† Soc¬†‚Äì Some¬†Distribution¬†or mailing list
¬†¬†¬†¬† Team ‚Äì¬†Some¬†Distribution¬†or mailing list
¬†¬†¬†¬† Team ‚Äì¬†Some¬†Distribution¬†or mailing list
¬†¬†¬†¬† Team ‚Äì¬†Some¬†Distribution¬†or mailing list
¬†¬†¬†¬† Team ‚Äì¬†Some¬†Distribution¬†or mailing list
¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†Tech ‚Äì¬†Some¬†Distribution¬†or mailing list
¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†Tech ‚Äì¬†Some¬†Distribution¬†or mailing list
¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†Tech ‚Äì¬†Some¬†Distribution¬†or mailing list
¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†Tech ‚Äì¬†Some¬†Distribution¬†or mailing list
¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†Tech ‚Äì¬†Some¬†Distribution¬†or mailing list
¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†Tech ‚Äì¬†Some¬†Distribution¬†or mailing list
¬†¬†Reference

First these are just fictitous names of distribution lists (duh!). I use prefixes to apply order to my inbox folders. I like to have administrative type folders at the top of my folder heirarchy so I prefix those with an @ sign. A number of these were created by the Getting Things Done Add-in, it automaticaly moves mails related to actions, delegations or waiting for.

You‚Äôll also see Accepted Meeting requests, I automatically have confirmation mails for folks attending meetings I set up moved to this folder.

Weblog referrals are referrals from this blog that Dasblog kindly notifies me of.

Autogroup is an internal tool we use for managing distribution lists that I get notifications of people asking to join lists that I own internally. This is all pretty admininistrative and I like to have it grouped together.

The next set of prefixes I use are for my distribution lists. These are:

Biz ‚Äì Business related / broad discussion on a core business
Dog ‚Äì Beta testing of pre-release software or dogfooding as we call it here at Microsoft
Soc ‚Äì Social discussion (Canucks at Microsoft or XBox discussion)
Team ‚Äì Team mailing lists like our uber organization, my direct reports or my peers.
Tech ‚Äì Deep technical discussions like C# Discussion or Tablet PC Development

Last but not least you‚Äôll see the folder called Reference. Would you belive I store reference materials across hundreds of projects and individuals in one folder? Am I nuts? Nope, and I don‚Äôt usually use search either to find what I am looking for.

How do I do it? This reference folder uses Outlook 20003‚Äôs custom folder views to organize the data by project. More on that in the next section.

The layout above gives minimal heirarchy, I can quickly expand and collapse it down to keep my focus on my inbox. If I need to keep extra focus on a particular distribution list, I add it to my Favorite Folders list in Outlook and its placed in Outlook‚Äôs favorite folder Window so I can monitor it very closely for activity. As soon as its bold, it catches my eye and I can pounce on it!

**Custom Folder Views
** This works best for project management, if you use the Getting Things Done Add
-i
n I talked about in my
previous post. With the GTD Add-in you have a file button where you can assign a Project name to the mail. This additional metadata for my email allows me to organize my Reference folder into expandable/collapsible groups organized by Getting Things Done Project Name.

To apply this to a folder right click on the gray column headings and a context menu will appear and select Arrange By -> Custom

From the Customize View dialog box select the Group By dialog and finally the Group By Dialog. Here you want to choose User-Defined Fields in folder from the Select available fields from drop down button and set Group items by to Project.

Bing! You now have a folder organized by Getting Things Done Projects. It is a Much better than a sprawling list of folders that is very hard to manage. The good news is if a project changes a name you can reclassify things on¬†mass using the Getting Things Done Admin menu.

**Closing
** So thats all I do, this is how I manage my mail. Give this a try and let me know if this helps clean out your inbox and manage your mail more effectively.

I‚Äôve been using these strategies in one form or another for the last 7 years. For the most part my inbox sits at about 15-20 items throughout the day, lets see what this can do for your bulging inbox today.

Enjoy!

item.title: How I get things done / Kicking some butt on your email inbox ‚Äì Part 1
item.description:
I get a lot of mail and wanted to share how I manage the large volumes of email, tasks and information that I get while working at Microsoft. I use a variety of tools to help me incorporate David Allen‚Äôs getting things done methodolgy¬†(GTD) and they work really well for me. As more and more folks come to me and ask me about information management it was time to create something permanent ‚Äúthat scales‚Äù as we say at Microsoft so I can share the knowledge.

I will divide this into two posts:

  1. Getting started with Getting things done and the Outlook add-in
  2. The right use of Outlook rules¬†and folder management for reference

When I talk to folk about Getting things done they often say things like, ‚ÄúOh I have a system already‚Äù or ‚ÄúI am able to juggle lots of things in my brain and toggle between them quickly, I don‚Äôt need a system like GTD.‚Äù

To be honest I was in this camp too but came to the point where I was losing creative energy. Lenn put me on to Getting Things Done about two years ago and it has been life changing.¬†

With Getting things done, I am laser focussed, I am creative and I‚Äôve gained valuable time back into my life. David makes the following point, ‚ÄúHow can you be creative and free when you braining is reverberating with phrases like Gotta go to the bank‚Ä¶ Gotta follow up with the architect‚Ä¶ Need to send email to my boss‚Ä¶ Need to write that report.. ‚Äú.

You can‚Äôt‚Ä¶

You need to get this data out of your pshycic ram and into a knowledge capture device. (e.g. a tape recorder, a PDA, a notepad or computer). Then use tactics like daily and weekly reviews to create a strategy for attacking the items. Me, I do a daily review every morning around 7:00 am while having a morning coffee. I also do a 1 hour weekly review Friday afternoons to set broader strategies in place for long term issues and bigger projects.

**Step 1 ‚Äì Getting Started
** First off you need to read David‚Äôs short book¬†or listen to his audio book¬†then come back to this post. üôÇ

Personally, I tried reading the book, but was more succesful with the audio book instead. The book is split in two parts, the first part is David giving an overview of how to manage information and the second part is about implementing the program. I listened to part one on my commute to work and then in part two I listened to, in my office while putting the program to action.

It was just like having David in my office helping me to get the program in place. I rewinded and paused the recording as I worked through the process of file folders, organizing your email, etc. David charges big dollars to executives around the world to¬†provide personal coaching. Don‚Äôt tell David¬†about my secret üôÇ¬†

Just start doing some of the things he he says and you‚Äôll regain valuable time and focus back into your world, do them all and you‚Äôll change your life.

**Step 2 ‚Äì Working with Outlook
** Once you get David‚Äôs base system in place you‚Äôll find that you‚Äôre wrestling with Outlook, you need to use the add-in. For me personally, I don‚Äôt think I really got traction with the system until I started using the Getting Things Done Outlook Add-in.¬† Using the add-in saves you time and forces you into a new habit of managing your mail, tasks and projects. Don‚Äôt think of it like training wheels, in fact think of it like super-charging Outlook for productivity.

In Getting Things Done, you look at email as it comes in and ask yourself the following questions:

  • Does this mail matter, can I delete it? No? ‚Äî Delete it!
  • Can I resolved this mail in less than two minutes? Yes? Do it!
  • Should someone else be doing this mail? ‚Äî Delegate it
  • Will this take me longer than two minutes? ‚Äî Defer it!
  • Is this reference material? ‚Äî File it and assign it to a project or category

The Getting Things Done Outloook add-in, adds a set of buttons to outlook for managing your information. While reviewing your¬†Inbox¬†you‚Äôll select these depending on what you need to do.¬†

Delegate
Selecting this generates a dialog asking which project you would like to assign the task to (if you don‚Äôt have one on file, you can create a new project) and who to delegate this to. It then pops up Outlook‚Äôs standard email form so you can send them a note. Last but not least it, automatically places a ‚Äúwaiting for‚Äù task on your task list so that you‚Äôve got something to track that you are waiting for a response.

Defer
Ever get something on your email that you want to defer to a particular date/time to work on? Defer automatically blocks out time on your calendar to work on the task

Action
This is the button I use the most of all. It allows me to take an email and assign it to a task. It preserves the original mail, moving the mail out of my inbox and placing it on my task list organized by action type. (phone calls, computer work with internet connection, computer work without internet, agenda items, etc).

Someday
This pops up a dialog for items that you want to file under Somday/Maybe and create a task. These are those high level 50,000 feet items like the email you’ve got about an opportunity to climb mount everest, etc.

Snooze
This is one my favorite options. Ever hold things in your inbox because you know you want to do them soon, but they can wait a week or so? Click the snooze button… Doing this moves the item out of your inbox for the specified time period and it will magically reappear in your inbox in the time you specified.

File
I’ll talk more about this in a later post. The file button is awesome. As mail comes in and I need to file it, I just select this button and it automatically puts it in my reference folder and tags it with the project name.

Would you believe I use one folder for all my reference materials?

Until I did it this way, I had a mess of project folder heirarchy in Outlook. I spent more time trying to remember what my personal taxonomy was. Now I have one folder and with Outlook custom folder views, I can always find the information I use organized by project type. To succeed you need a fast search for Outlook like Lookout’s search , but this was a time saving thing for me..

So this is the first step on k
ic
king some butt on your ema
il inbox. In part 2 I’ll go over strategies for rules and managing your reference material.

Let me know if this helps and if you are using different tactics for Getting Things Done and information management.

Cheers!

item.title: Powdered Shakes, Working out and getting into the flow of a new job
item.description:
What an amazing week!

I‚Äôve made it through the first 7 days of the 20/20 program. The past week has been full of big changes for me. The first part is the diet change which has been hard but not impossible. I met with my dietician and she gave me a bunch of vitamins and minerals (fish oil caplets, calcium and daily multi vitamins), a log book to record eactly what I eat each day, the calories and the total fat.

The more important part that she gave me was a box of metabolic protein shakes and¬†a menu for 7 days that looks something like this:

**Breakfast
** Protein Powder + 1 Tablespoon Peanut Butter + 1 Teaspoon Fiber Powder + 1/2 Cup Berries

**Morning Snack
** Protein Powder + 1/2 Cup Berries

**Lunch
** Protein Powder + 1/2 ¬†Cup Berries + 6 ounces Tuna + 1 Teaspoon Mayo

**Afternoon Snack
** Protein Powder + 1 /2 Cup Berries

**Dinner
** Protein Powder + 1/2 Cup Berries + 6 ounces of a boneless chicken breast

I can substitute blueberries, strawberries, blackberries or marionberries in for the berries and a variety of lean proteins for the meals. I am still allowed to have 8 ounces of coffee (black no sugar, no cream) per day, but have noticed that I am not having it very often. I am also drinking over 64 ounces of water per day.

Its been hard, lots of withdrawl symptoms (headaches, grumpyness, ¬†moodyness) but not as bad as I had thought. I friend who went through this awhile back recommended to me that I try and taper off coffee and sugars well before I started this first phase. Doing so was a big help and made this a lot easier.

In addition to this I am working out with a trainer 3 times per week (lots of cardio and some weight training) and am working on my own twice per week (jogging).

So most importantly not to ask what I am doing, how am I doing? I feel awesome. I am not hungry throughout the day, I am passed the detox period and the headaches are gone. The workout sessions are great and last night was the first time that I‚Äôve felt a bit sore from my workout.

Only 21 more weeks to go!

item.title: Ch-ch-ch-ch-Changes (Turn and face the stranger) ‚Äî New Job for Jeff at Microsoft
item.description:
I am starting my eighth year at Microsoft and although this last year was chalk full of amazing experiences, building Channel 9, it was time for some changes.

For those that don‚Äôt know me I started at Microsoft in PSS supporting Visual InterDev 1.0 and Active Server Pages 1.0. I did that for about two years and went on to work in Visual Studio / MSDN. I worked in this group as a Program Manager building sites like Code Center¬†and Lighthouse which was a service for the Visual Studio Shell that provided up to date data from MSDN to the shell. I eventually ended up leading a small team of PMs and we did a re-design of MSDN and Technet, an update to the MSDN offline Library and new viewer technology for TechNet.

I‚Äôve always been an Evangelist at heart and since my career aspirations from my day one at Microsoft were to be an Evangelist I made the move back to an individual contributer (no employees) and moved to the Platform Strategy Group (now known as Developer and Platform Evangelism or D&PE).

My first project was to get an understanding of how Web Services would be used in the enterprise. I worked with Garland Brown and we created a set of Web Services that communicated with Microsoft‚Äôs own Siebel environment allowing folks to communicate with Siebel via an ASP.NET web based interface.

This was back in the alpha days of Visual Studio.NET and was break through work. The work here ultimately led to the Alchemy Web Services in Microsoft IT. I learnt a lot about patience in that project, negotiating with internal groups and built a great friendship with Garland brown who later went on to take an Architect Evangelist role for Microsoft in Arizona.

With Alchemy complete it was time for the next thing so I moved over to help Steve Cellini with planning for the PDC. I partnered with Steve on a lot of the community efforts and other administrivia helping make the event happen. What an incredible ride that was!

When the PDC was over it was time to take our community and transparency efforts to the next level and Lenn asked me to partner with him to build Channel 9. This was probably the most fun I‚Äôve had ever at Microsoft. It was just go, go go and make big things happen. Lenn and I were in perfect sync throughout the project and I loved every minute of it.

With Channel 9 out the door though now I was left wondering what to go after next. I was asking myself what was I passionate about and also where did my group need me?

It turns out our team had an opening for a Group Manager leading the Tools and Components Evangelism Team reporting to¬†Steve Cellini. So after some thought knowing that I love Developer Tools and had worked for Steve during the PDC and enjoyed it, it was time to make the move and build a team again.

I am now leading an Evangelism Team where we work with early adopters for Visual Studio Tools for Office and Visual Studio Team System. In addition to this we‚Äôll work with early adopters for VSIP¬† around vendors supplying components and tools for Visual Studio and Team System.

Its an exciting change, meaning lots for me to learn and do.

Microsoft is constantly giving me good changes and excitement. I look at the years I‚Äôve spent here and its been amazing, constant challenge, constant change and the ability to move quickly and get things done.

Being able to move onto new things regularly is a good thing. For one it keeps you challenged and also keeps the organization moving too. I no longer will be officially working on Channel 9 (but you can bet I‚Äôll be constantly giving Scoble and gang lots of video and featutre ideas). Charles from the Channel 9 team is going to step up and take over a lot of the things I did. Ivan who did the Junktop Revival Laptop will also move over to Channel 9. I‚Äôm going to really miss working for Lenn¬†but am also looking forward to working for Steve.

So we‚Äôre on our way, David Allen strategies on hand (I am in jujuitso email mode) we‚Äôre on our way.

Wish me luck!

P.S. I‚Äôm hiring üôÇ

¬†

item.title: I'm on my way to 20/20 Life
item.description:
While on vacation this summer and doing some work around the house, I did not have the energy I used to have. Carrying furniture around and moving things up and down stairs made me sweat like a pig. I‚Äôd lose my breath and got tired needing a break before the job was done. To think I used to race BMX and ride motocross, where did it go?

Up until the the last few years I could eat lots of anything and my metabolism would make it go away. Now I just seem to be packing on the pounds and am not very proud of the weight I‚Äôve put on to date. To make matters worse I did a BMI calculation to find that I was considered obsese (BMI > then 30.0 and above). Would you believe that 80 per cent of Americans over the age of 25 are overweight by BMI?

So what to do I do about it?

I was burnt out on diets and wasn‚Äôt interested in jumping on the Atkins or Zone bandwagon. I did it before and couldn‚Äôt keep it off. I wanted to do this so badly though. So I can make a positive change, both for me and also so to have an influence on my daughter Josie. So I thought I‚Äôd check out a program at the Pro Club¬†called 20/20 Lifestyles. A number of friends and co-workers have gone through this and have had amazing success, maybe it would work for me.

My wife and I decided to check out an overview session in early September and were quite impressed. The program is tailored to the individual and is intense. A typical week consists of :

  • Individual counseling with a registered dietitian
    • Viewing of educational videos while exercising
      • Exercising with a certified personal trainer (for 1.5 hours, 3 times per week)

        • Support group meeting for lifestyle modification and disorder education

          • Weekly review of client‚Äôs progress
          • Exercising on your own (1.5 hours 2 times per week)
          Instead of going on a ‚Äúdiet‚Äù this is a lifestyle change, adjusting my diet to include foods that work for me and changing my schedule so I can exercise regularly.

        I jumped on board and began the process of Doctor‚Äôs exams to figure out what is the right weight target for me. I really just got rolling with the program about a week ago, completing my intake examination (stress test) and my first session with my personal trainer. I really enjoyed the time working out.

        Tomorrow I meet with my dietician for the first time. I think seeing the dietician¬†will be key. Everyone‚Äôs requirements for foods is different and the dietician works with you to add and remove things from your diet in order to achieve a balance.

        One part for the next week that I know is going to be very hard is that I will drastically reducing the solid food that I eat to baseline myself. For the next 7 days (I think) I‚Äôll be going on meal replacement shakes and supplement them with boneless/skinless chicken breasts and some fruit. This is to help get my blood sugar right and get rid of any insulin resistance¬†that I might have. This way I can start to take the weight off. Bye bye sugar and massive doses of caffeine.

        I‚Äôm hoping that this will not be as much of a shock to me, I knew it was coming so I started to tape it off. In fact its been about 3 weeks since I‚Äôve had a coke or any other carbonated beverage from the fridges at work. I‚Äôve switched to bottled water and am now down to one 8 ounce cup of black coffee per day (down from multiple Vente Mochas per week). Its been hard just to cut this out of my routine.

        So where I am headed? Hopefully success. For the next 10 weeks I am in the intense portion of the program. I am hoping to lose about 30 pounds. I‚Äôll then move into maintenance mode which lasts 12 weeks. In maintenance mode I‚Äôll see the trainer only twice a week.

        When done I‚Äôm want to run regularly,¬†be able to take a spinning class without throwing up and just feel good inside and how I look outside. I hope I can do this.

        I‚Äôm on my way, wish me luck!

item.title: Flexwiki goes to Sourceforge.net
item.description:
David Writes:

This evening FlexWiki took the next step in its life and has been made available at SourceForge.net under the Common Public License. With this step, the developer community will have the latest source (including all the WikiTalk features), better access, better tools, and a better legal environment.  The FlexWiki developer community has kinda stalled out a bit over the past few months as I’ve worked to get FlexWiki to this point.  Now we can really get going again!As I was thinking about what I’d write in the blog entry, I found myself enumerating questions that I thought people would have.

Flexwiki is the software we used for Channel 9’s Wiki implementation and something I’ve used to document a number of projects inside Microsoft. Its really cool to see another Microsoft project up on SourceForge under a the Common Public License.

Congratulations to the folks who planted the seed here, hopefully lots of good comes from this.

Long live the wiki!

item.title: Photos from Farm Aid
item.description:
Josie, Lauri and I went to the Farm Aid Concert in at the White River Ampitheater last night. This was Josie‚Äôs first major concert. This is the 19th Farm Aid Concert. I‚Äôve watched them on television ever since I can remember. think Lauri and I started donating to Farm Aid shortly after we moved to the United States from Canada. My grandfather farmed and I have great memories being out on the farm with him during harvest. I think it was Neil Young last night that said, ‚ÄúWouldn‚Äôt you rather get your food from a farmer that feeds the same food to his family?‚Äù

Our seats were great, right down front and center with a great view of the stage. We had a cool surprise shortly after finding our seats. While getting Josie comfortable with ear plugs and her Polly Pockets¬†a person from the Farm Aid organization popped over to say hi and ask us how we like our seats.

She produced lanyards with a laminated guest of Farm Aid card on them. We thanked her, but weren‚Äôt exactly sure what they were for. The girl told us that these would give us full access backstage where we‚Äôd find food, other families and of course kids for Josie to play with. We thanked her and continued to watch the warm up bands play.

The backstage passes were cool, but to be honest I‚Äôve been backstage at a couple of events before and always felt out of place. I wasn‚Äôt sure if we‚Äôd use them or not. This was a nice treat though from the Farm Aid folks.

A little bit later the Farm Aid girl returned (I feel awful I can‚Äôt remember her name) with a Dad and a little girl Josie‚Äôs age and said, ‚ÄúJosie! This little girl who‚Äôd like to meet you‚Äù. The girl was named Rowen and her Dad was Shawn. Turns out Rowen‚Äôs mom is Wendy. Wendy is a director of Farm Aid along with Sky someone who I‚Äôve communicated over email with for some time. Rowen asked if Josie if she wanted to pack up her Polly‚Äôs and maybe do some coloring backstage. So we decided to take them up on their offer and we were escorted backstage.

Baskstage was very cool and quite different than my previous experiences. There were families members of the artists, Farm Aid staff and volunteers. Everyone was watching the concert, eating fresh, family farm grown food Salmon, Brisket and Vegetables. Artists were playing XBox games and everyone was having a great time. It was awesome! Josie and Rowen dumped out a bag of Polly Pockets on the table and played with them and also colored.

Lauri and I had got some food from the buffet and got to know Shawn a lot better and Wendy popped over to say hi. Wendy and Shawn are from Boston where Farm Aid‚Äôs headquarters is located. The girls played for awhile and we enjoyed food and great conversation.

Later I was able to check out the infrastructure that they were using to drive the Farm Aid Streamcast for the event, it was all streamed in Windows Media 9. The website infrastructure is using software called Convio¬†created during the Dean Campaign and now being adopted by a number of non-profits including Farm Aid.

After eating our food, the girls were ready to get back to the concert and dance. Rowen and Shawn joined us at our seats just as Steve Earle got on stage. Josie and Rowen rocked out to Copperhead Road¬†and continued there dance tribute to Farm Aid for a number of sets. While Jerry Lee Lewis¬†was playing Lauri stayed and watched his performance and I took Josie and Rowen backstage for cake.

Jerry Lee Lewis blew us away, what amazing energy, I hope I have that kind of energy in 10 years let alone 40 years from now. He rocked the house.

Josie and I got back to our seats (Rowen stayed with her mom and Dad backstage) and we were just in time for Dave Matthews‚Äô performance which was over the top. I‚Äôve never seen Dave play live before. The cool thing about the Farm Aid event was all performances seemed to be in the MTV Unplugged style. Accoustically instruments, not too loud so you could really hear the artist sing.

John Mellancamp came on stage and was great too, the crowd went nuts when he broke into Rain on the scarecrow.

Rain on the scarecrow, Blood on the plow
This land fed a nation, this land made me proud
And Son I’m just sorry theres’ no legacy for you now
Rain on the scarecrow, blood on the plow
Rain on the scarecrow, blood on the plow

The line in this song that gives me chills and brings a tear to my eye¬†is, ‚ÄúWell theres 97 crosses planted in the courthouse yard 97 families who lost 97 farms‚Äù.

One thing about John‚Äôs performance was his smoking. He seemed to start a new cigarette every time he did a new song. Didn‚Äôt he have heart surgery back a few years ago?

Neil Young then came on stage and Josie drifted off to sleep on my lap to Pochantis. In between each song he reminded folks about Family Farms. ‚ÄúDid you know that when Farm Aid started we were losing a thousand family farms a week. Now the number is down to 390, which means we‚Äôre failing‚Äù. Sad, 390 families a week no longer bring us food that they also eat to your table.

Willie Nelson finished off the evening with a medley of songs. He played old favorites, some blues pieces. Amazing performance.

With the evening complete Josie was sacked out in my lap. I carried her to the car and Lauri hauled along the Polly bags and other toys we brought along. We made the trek home, getting back to the house around midnight.

I can just imagine though that this has probably set Josie‚Äôs expectations for concerts a bit too high for the future. I am pretty sure that next concert we go to Josie won‚Äôt be eating catered food and playing Pollies backstage. üôÇ

What an amazing experience. Thank you Sky, Wendy, Shawn and Rowen for your hospitality. What an amazing event. Thank you Farm Aid.

If the Farm Aid event is in your area next year don‚Äôt miss it and more importantly if you care about Family Farming in America, please visit the Farm Aid site to learn more and make a donation today. When buying food, try and do it at a Farmers Market like Pike Place in Seattle.

Cheers! üôÇ

P.S. More pictures are here.

item.description:
I‚Äôm spending the weekend up in Sebastopol, California for a private event. Driving up from San Francisco this afternoon I stumbled across the Glenn Beck radio program. Glenn was talking about how he dreamt for the day that 9/10 would return. You know all of us remember where we were on 9/11, but I am not sure if we all remember where we were on 9/10.

Glenn played a very touching audio compilation of radio programs, aircraft tower transmissions and other coverage from the day. Spooky and touching. Please take a moment to listen to the piece, it is available here from Glenn‚Äôs site.

Honestly? It brought tears to my eyes as I made my way up Highway 101 this afternoon. I can‚Äôt remember where I was on 9/10, I do remember the morning of 9/11 and feeling like I got kicked in the stomach. I think a lot of us felt that way.

My heart and my prayers goes out to the souls that were lost on 9/11 as we pass another anniversary of this fateful day.

Peace üôÇ

item.title: Welcome to Saskatchewan ‚Äì Email from my mom
item.description:
Welcome to Saskatchewan. Thank you for visiting our beautiful province. Here are a few things you ought to know to make your stay more pleasant:

  1. That slope-shouldered farm boy you are snickering at did more work before breakfast than you will do all week at the gym.

  2. It‚Äôs called a ‚Äúgravel road.‚Äù No matter how slow you drive, you‚Äôre going to get dust on your BMW. I have a 4-wheel drive because I need¬† it. Now drive or get it out of the way.

  3. We all started hunting and fishing when we were nine-years-old. Yeah, we saw Bambi die. We got over it.

  4. Any references to ‚Äúgrain fed‚Äù when talking about our women will get your butt kicked ‚Ä¶ by our women.

  5. Pull your pants up, and turn your hat around. You look like an idiot.

  6. If that cell phone rings while a bunch of mallards are making their final approach, we will shoot it. You might hope you don‚Äôt have it up to your ear at the time.

  7. No, there‚Äôs no ‚ÄúVegetarian Special‚Äù on the menu. Order steak. Order it rare. Or, you can order the Chef‚Äôs Salad and pick off the two pounds of ham and turkey.

  8. Yeah, we have sweet tea. It comes unsweetened in a glass with two packets of sugar and a long spoon.

  9. You bring Coke into my house you better bring rye along, and some ice.

  10. So you have a sixty-thousand-dollar car. We‚Äôre real impressed. We¬† have quarter-million-dollar combines that we use two weeks a year.

  11. Let‚Äôs get this straight. We may have one stoplight in town, but we stop when it‚Äôs red. We may even stop when it‚Äôs yellow.

  12. Our women hunt, fish, and drive trucks ‚Äì because they want to. So, you re a feminist. Isn‚Äôt that cute.

  13. Yeah, we eat trout, Northern pike, walleye, and perch, too. If¬† you really want sushi and caviar, it‚Äôs available at the bait shop.

  14. They are pigs and cows. That‚Äôs what they smell like. Get over it. Don‚Äôt like it? Highways #1 and #16 go two ways ‚Äì get on one of them.

  15. The ‚ÄúOpener‚Äù refers to the first days of fishing and deer season.¬† They are religious holidays. You can get breakfast at the church.

  16. So what if every person in every pick-up waves? It‚Äôs called being friendly. Understand the concept?

  17. Yeah, we have golf courses. Don‚Äôt hit into the water hazards. It¬† spooks the fish. And stay out of the woods. It‚Äôll spook the deer.

Please enjoy your stay. Eh.

item.title: Banff Sulpfur Mountain Summit
item.description:
Reading Dave‚Äôs post about staying in Banff tonight brings back great childhood memories as I spent a good part of my early childhood in Kamloops, British Columbia moving to Saskatchewan in the fifth grade.

Each summer our family would make the trip back to Saskatchewan for vacation which was at least a two day trip. Banff was the perfect spot to pull over and get out of the car to take a break. We‚Äôd always get to stop off at the Sulphur mountain gondola and make the ride to the top.

A few years back I was able to repeat the tradition with my own family. When you get to the top you aren‚Äôt actually at the true summit, but they‚Äôve got a nice pathway that I believe is wheel chair accessible that allows you to take a walk to the summit.

It will be interesting what Dave thinks about the trip as takes the Roger‚Äôs Pass and the curvey roads near Golden, British Columbia. As I child these roads freaked me out and I would hide on the floor in the back seat of my parents car:-). Later in life driving them as an adult with my own family they didn‚Äôt seem to be that big of a deal. We‚Äôd also stop at the Roger‚Äôs Pass Summit and at the CP Rail Spiral Tunnel information booth, an interesting part of Canadian railroad history. We‚Äôd also fill up water jugs from the waterfalls that cascade down the mountains along Roger‚Äôs pass, the water was so cold, but so fresh. My Dad had a CB Radio in his car and we‚Äôd listen in on the trucker conversations as we‚Äôd make the trip. Fun

Dave, it has been a real treat watching and listening as you make your trek. I‚Äôve lived in all the provinces that he‚Äôs crossed. I was born in Kamloops, British Columbia, spent most of years in Estevan, Saskatchewan, went to college in Calgary, Alberta and had my first job out of college in Winnipeg, Manitoba.

Thank you!

item.title: Back from WSU ‚Äì The XM Radio made a 5 hour drive awesome
item.description:
We‚Äôre back from taking Brynn off for her freshman year at WSU.¬†She‚Äôs all settled in and ready to experience campus life. The Pullman area reminded me of¬†the farming community where I grew up, Estevan, Saskatchewan. Here‚Äôs a snapshot I took on the road home, just outside of Pullman.

There is nothing quite as soothing as a warm summer night on the prairies, the smell of freshly harvested wheat and the open road. üôÇ

This was the first extended drive I‚Äôve taken since buying my XM Satellite Radio.¬†This really transformed my trip, no more searching the dial for something good on, tonnes of content to choose from.¬†We listened to CNN, FoxNews, Al Franken and a Biography on E! about the gameshow the Family Feud.¬†All day content, no interruptions.

item.title: WSU Day 2 ‚Äì Getting Brynn's computer on the network
item.description:
It day two of getting Brynn all setup at Washington State University.¬†I am very impressed with how the University practices safe computing.¬†

In order to get Brynn‚Äôs computer onto the university network, the Resident Assistant came in with a disk which had all the latest patches for Windows XP and complimentary anti-virus software. She had a screenshot of the add/remove programs user interface too to make sure that all the required patches were installed to do a quick compare.¬†Brynn of course already was running service pack 2, had her firewall on an was running Norton Antivirus so she was good to go.¬† It was after this review that the Resident Assistant turned on her network port in her dorm room.¬† Wireless seems to require a VPN client so we‚Äôll save that for another day.

Upon first connection Brynn had to register her MAC Physical Address for the network card and supply addiition information about her machine.¬† After that she was all set.¬†This was all done with a slick little sign-on application all written in ASP.NET üôÇ üôÇ

I am back at the hotel with our youngest daughter now watching her swim.¬† Mom is hanging out at the dorm room with Brynn.¬†

This is a bitter sweet week, full of emotions.¬†¬†You see¬†we‚Äôre excited for Brynn to start something new , something that we‚Äôve talked about forever and it means a change in our role as parents.¬† It is time to have confidence in the things we‚Äôve taught her as her parents.¬†

We all feel a bit edgy, lots of tears and also laughter (Weird mix) seam to be the order of the day. üôÇ

item.title: Thanks Jim Blizzzard for the help with BlogJet
item.description:
I‚Äôm playing with BlogJet¬†today.¬† So far the biggest benefit is that it makes it very easy for me to include local images with my posts.¬† I just insert the image file with the WYSIWYG editor and browse for the local copy of the image.¬† BlogJet takes it from there and automatically transfers the file to my server and creates the correct path to the image in the HTML for my post.

I did have one heck of a time configuring all this though, no matter how hard I tried I couldn‚Äôt get the test configuration screen to work.¬† After searching I found the solution to the problem here on Jim Blizzard‚Äôs blog.¬† It turns out that when BlogJet was trying to send the test file to my host (Webhost4life.com)

It turns out BlogJet needed the full path to where I wanted to stuff the FTP files.¬† For Webhost4Life the path is /c:/hosting/webhost4life/member/myUserID/images¬† As Jim states the beginning slash (/) in the Remote Folder field is important. The virtual address in the Base URL has to point to the physical folder¬†you type into the Remote Folder field.

Thankfully the BlogJet team has a test this configuration option on this screen as it enabled me to troubleshoot the problem easily.¬†

item.title: Our mural girl now has a weblog
item.description:
Last fall I decided to do something special for my wife.¬† Lauri has always been completely supportive of my work at Microsoft and I wanted to make her birthday very special.¬† You see our dining room has twenty foot ceilings and is a very nice space, but the walls were plain, we‚Äôd looked over and over for the right piece of art but nothing seemed to fit in.¬† I wanted to get something for her that would make a big impact on the look of this space.

The long story short is that we ended up meeting a wonderful gal named Jody Anderson at Bellevue Square who was doing some chalk art on the sidewalk and we began talking about murals for our dining room.¬†Details on the complete project are detailed in earlier posts on my weblog.¬†The mural turned out to be amazing; Jody became and extended part of our family over the many weeks that she came to our home to paint. In fact the completion of the mural was bittersweet.¬†We were thrilled to have it complete, but sad that Jody was not going to be coming to our house each day.

The other night Jody called to say that she‚Äôs going into the mural business full time and would like to get a website up. She really liked the way that I displayed regular updates on my weblog showing the inspiration for the project and the progression of the mural and wanted to know if we could setup a home page for her upcoming work and to also display previous pieces.¬†¬†

The weblog lets us know more about the Jody the person not just the products she creates. Through her weblog you‚Äôll be able to see both the inspiration and also the making of her past and future murals. If she does interesting things, folks will hopefully link to her, building up her rank in Google and making her easily discoverable which will hopefully result in some new business.

Jody will be using Blogger.com as the publishing engine, Webhost4life.com as the host and BlogJet as the front end.¬†¬† Blogger.com was a good engine for the site, the supplied templates are nice looking and can be easily customized.¬†¬† She wanted to build her own identity and personal brand, so rather than hosting at Blogspot.com she used Webhost4life and registered the domain name. We needed to make it easy to get images into her post without having to learn the idiosyncrasies of ftp and file transfer. BlogJet really shines at making everything much simpler for Jody.¬†¬† This cool application lets Jody add pictures to her posts and they are automatically ftp‚Äôd to the server. She can also build drafts of posts and publish them later when they are complete.¬†

This all was very inexpensive and it was all quite easy to stitch together.

Blogger.com¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† free
Webhost4life.com¬† $59.40¬†($4.95 / month)
BlogJet¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† $19.95
‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî
¬†Total Cost¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† $79.35

Jody has just begun getting content up on her weblog, you can get a sneak peak of it at themuralartist.com. One interesting thing is that Blogger.com doesn‚Äôt support RSS, but thanks to the folks at 2RSS.com and their Atom to RSS conversion service, Jody now has an RSS feed too. Subscribed.

item.title: Build your own XM Radio Home Kit
item.description:
I want to listen to my Roady in the house.¬† It is made to be used in my car.¬† There is a home kit for it¬†that I am supposed to get as part of a rebate program. Rebates suck, I hate waiting 4-6 weeks.¬†

I want to listen to my Roady in the house now and don‚Äôt want to wait anymore.¬† Today just as I was about to order it from the web I had a Magyver moment.¬†

Across my office I spied the A/C adapter for my portable fridge which can be pluged into the wall or a cigarette lighter.¬† In fact the fridge‚Äôs adapter can power any cigarette lighter powered device.¬† So I packed it up the little A/C adapter and took it home with me.¬†

I plugged the XM Radio‚Äôs power supply into my fridge‚Äôs adapter, woohoo no sparks and no blown fuses.¬† I plugged the satellite antenna into the device and it was displaying channels and song titles.¬† I tuned my FM Radio to 107.3 and was happy to hear music.

I didn‚Äôt think it would work as I was worried that the antenna wouldn‚Äôt pick up a signal from inside my house but it works.¬† Its good enough for now, the docking station for the home kit will be nice as I won‚Äôt have to lug my antenna inside and out, but this works for now.

item.title: An old friend is going to Berkley ‚Äì He wrote the first social network I've ever used
item.description:
An old time friend, Jordan Breckenridge is off to Berkley to get his MBA.¬†¬† Jordan and I spent our younger years programming Commodore 64 and Commodore 128 computers and hanging out on Bulletin Board Systems.¬†¬† Our parents took turns giving us rides to and from each others houses.¬† Together we hung out, shared programs and talked about building applications.

One of the coolest programs Jordan wrote back in the day (high school) was a modern day equivalent of Orkut.¬† Jordan handed out surveys out in home room across the high school.¬† Students answered questions about their personality and interests.¬† With the data on hand Jordan entered the data (hopefully the SRC helped, but I can‚Äôt remember) in his computer.¬† Weeks later on Valentines day each student received a list of what folks of the opposite sex they were most compatible.¬† Now if only Jordan had updated the code, registered the domain name and saught VC funding maybe he‚Äôd be retired.¬†¬†

Great though on photos on Jordan‚Äôs website, whenever I get home sick for Saskatchewan I go and look at this page.¬† My favorite photos are:


Combine ‚Äî Reminds me of my grandfather who passed away when I was very young.¬† I used to love riding on the combine with him.


Prairie Church¬†‚Äî My grandmother took care of a small church in the town of Benson (population 100 people) and I remember to this day going with her as she got the sacrement and bibles ready for mass and me playing in the choir loft or helping her carry things.

Car Dust¬†‚Äî People joke that Saskatchewan is the only place where you can watch your dog run away for two days.¬† üôÇ¬† There is something surreal about being in the middle of nowhere and watching a car come across the prairies.¬† Chances are its someone you know.¬† I love small towns.

Thank you for the great pictures Jordan and enjoy your times at Berkley.

item.title: XM Radio and XML Encoding
item.description:
I am liking my XM Radio, I love listening to the comedy stations and also the 70‚Äôs, 80‚Äôs and 90‚Äôs Channels on my commute.¬† I never realized how many commercials local radio had until I got XM.¬† Sure XM has commercials on some channels, but nothing like regular radio does.

It looks like XM Radio uses XML in their backend too.¬† Just the other day while listening to the 80‚Äôs channel I had quite the surprise when I looked at the head unit.¬† The song play was Men at Work‚Äôs Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Jive.

Looks like XM Radio had a problem with their encoding scheme though when rendering song data.

Its so much fun being a geek and understanding these hidden secrets of modern devices.¬† Us geeks have such a different view into the world.¬†

My mom would look at this display and thing what a weird name for a song with @amp; instead of the expected &.¬†

I look at it and begin to wonder what their backend infrastructure is and wonder about their use of XML.¬†¬† I bet it would be easy for them to expose RSS feeds, but the question is why would they and what value would it serve customers?

My XM is great, my wife even likes it a lot.¬† I do have some requests though:

  • A harddrive or some form of solid state memory for recording.¬† I‚Äôd love to be able to rewind even just 3 minutes of a song (ala Tivo)
    • Show me what song is coming up next on a Channel, not just what‚Äôs playing now
      • Let me listen to the music on the web when at work, I‚Äôll pay more for my subscription if I can
      Its been a fun 30 days of XM Radio.¬† Anyone else using it?

item.title: Celebrate your nation's birthday by blowing up a piece of it ‚Äî I'm in
item.description:
It is almost the fourth of July and in true American ‚Äúwanna be‚Äú form I am off to buy fireworks.¬†

Why is that we celebrate our nation‚Äôs birthday by blowing up a piece of it?¬† We live in Sammamish, a small suburb of Seattle‚Äôs on the East side.¬† Each year my neighbor from across the street and I combine our collections of fireworks in the hopes of impressing our children and scaring the neighborhood dogs.¬† My youngest is almost 5 and and she loves to watch from the safety of the front windows.¬†

But, that is not what this is all about it is it?

No.¬† These are great weekends to reflect upon the freedoms we have, the rights we have¬†to speak our minds and the amazing opportunities available in America.¬† I can look at this nation from contrast, as I am originally from Canada.¬† I have had the opportunity to live through socialized medicine (trust me you don‚Äôt wan it), high taxes (read 55%) and a liberal government (I won‚Äôt go there).¬†

Sure I had great freedoms in Canada, but compared to the opportunities that can be found in the USA.¬† It has been an abosolute privilege to live here and I am very thankful.¬† So as I reflect this weekend upon the nation‚Äôs independence and our freedoms I have decided to take a big step.

I will be applying for naturalization as a United States citizen (aka Applying to become a citizen)

I‚Äôll chronicle the journey here on my weblog.¬† My previous application for permanent residency was quite the ride.¬† We‚Äôll see what the road ahead brings with this.

As a teenager in Canada, whenever I heard about an actor or actress from Canada becomning an American part of me was jealous, but I also wondered what made them do it and why?¬†

A year ago I ran into a fellow Canadian living in Toronto.¬† When he heard I was living in the USA, he shook my hand and congratulated me saying, ‚ÄúYou‚Äôve achieved the Canadian dream!¬† You now live in the USA‚Äú.¬† You are so fortunate.¬†

So why become an American?

There are many reasons, many deep some of which are‚Ä¶¬†

  • It is about being able to have a stake in your country through voting

    • My wife and both daughters are American. I‚Äôd love to be able to them the importantance of voting and of course vote together as a family

      • Its about this being a permantent home and becoming a member of the list of immigrants before me who‚Äôve helped to build this nation.
      The list of reasons goes on and on.¬† I am proud of my Canadian heritage and that will not be forgotten.¬† I am honored thought to be able to join this great country and am so thankful for all the opportunities granted to me here.

    Thank you America and thanks you to those that keep us free.

item.title: Everything I know about online community I learnt tending bar
item.description:
Photo credit: Jani Helle

Betsy‚Äôs recent post ‚ÄúWhat makes it a community‚Äù made me think about my own experiences running communities and the approach that I like to take.

Community has been part of my life for the past 20 years.¬† My first experience was with a homebrew Bulletin Board called The Nutwork that ran on my Commodore 64 out my parent‚Äôs basement.¬† This board ran faithfully on my Commodore 64 and eventually ended up running on my Amiga.

The Amiga based BBS was one of the first non-PC systems to join FidoNet.¬† FidoNet taught me the dynamics of having thousands of people participating in online discussions through echomail.¬† With the Internet came Usenet Newsgroups and later on web based forums all upping the ante on the fun things that happen when you get volumes of people interacting from the safety of their computer.

Today, I am a part of an experiment at Microsoft called Channel 9 which is a community that combines wikis, forums, weblogs and streaming video to give an insider‚Äôs view to Microsoft.

Enough with my online community resume onto the purpose of this post.¬† I am often asked by People who are starting an online community or involved in nurturing their community on how to handle the common scenarios your community will face in keeping conversations on topic, moving threads, etc.

In the spirit of Robert Fulghum and his book All I Really Need to Know I Learned in Kindergarten, I always reply, ‚ÄúAll I really need to know about online community I learnt tending bar‚Äù.

I like to think of online communities a lot like your would a neighborhood pub or a campus bar.¬† The administrators/moderators are the bar staff and the members are the folks who have stopped by for a drink, fellowship and entertainment.¬† Our job is to make a great place that you want to come back to again and¬†again.

We take this same approach in running Channel 9.

  • A good bartender knows when to be a part of the conversation and when not to.¬† If someone is alone and has no one to talk then the bar staff will often join in and make them feel at home.¬† If the crowd is having fun then they should just sit back and keep the bar clean.¬† That‚Äôs why sometimes we might be in a thread or we might just let one go and create a life of its own.
  • Sometimes the role of the staff is just to clean up the mess at the end of the day.¬† On a message board this usually means moving threads to the appropriate forums, deleting spam and fixing broken links in posts.¬†¬† I compare this to when bartenders make sure that the peanuts on the floor don‚Äôt start a fire or that there are no health code violations.
  • Patrons of a bar are free to choose what conversations they have at their table, they can talk about bars where there might be different music, better food or how much they don‚Äôt like the atmosphere of the current place.¬†¬† As long as they are not beligerant to other patrons thats¬†ok.¬†¬†¬†¬† On Channel 9 we have conversations about competing products, our products and even how we can improve.

The last bit is on tone.¬† Whenever we talk or post videos on Channel 9 we try and keep a peer to peer over a beer tone.¬† Someone coined that back in the Sitebuilder Network days at Microsoft and its stuck with me ever since.¬†¬† Its not about presentations and API slides it is about truly connecting with individuals, just like you would while having a talk over a beer.

item.title: BloggerCon ‚Äì Presidential Bloggers hosted by Dan Gilmor
item.description:
I am in the Presidential Blogging hosted by Dan Gilmor.¬† There are representatives here from all campaigns (Kerry, Dean, but no one from the Bush weblog).¬† The discussion is on how weblogs are being used by the parties to promote the candidates and engage in the community.

Is presidential blogging just another type of press release?
Its all about interaction.¬† If you don‚Äôt interact via comments and with the greater Blogosphere you‚Äôve only got a press release.¬† Being a part of the conversation is important.

What did the Clark Campaign Find?
The Clark campaign found a single blog didn‚Äôt scale for them.¬†¬† They tried it with movable type.¬† Instead of having 1 blog with 10,000 comments they created a community architecture.¬† More of a hybrid of blogs and forums.

**The Kerry Campaign
** Did not enjoy its time with Movable Type.¬†¬† Registration was very important and they had troll issues.¬† Another combination of forums and weblogs.¬† People really wanted threaded discussions, they have about 60 moderators from the community helping manage the forums.

Dean Campaign
Dave asks the question, did the campaign just become journalism?¬† Dave feels that the opponents did not beat Dean, CNN did.

‚ÄúKay O‚ÄôConnor‚Äôs posts in the Dean blog were some of the most popular. She was inside the campaign, with Dean, really behind the scenes.‚Äù

Should the candidates be blogging?
This is not realistic.¬† Personally, I think that they should once and awhile and even join in the conversation, but I think if you want them to win they need to spend time elsewhere.

**What did you learn from constituents through your weblog instead of focus groups?
** Kerry campaign tracks many things.. e.g. themes across many emails, what weblogs are saying.¬† Scale is a challenge, they care about getting millions of people to do things on one day.¬† Control is always on the message and how they keep people on message.¬†¬†

The campaigns learned¬†but not just through the blogs.¬† The Dean campaign got its best feedback from folks that organized using Meetup.com, not weblogs.

**Weblogs could show the human side of candidates
** A fellow who was on the Gore campaign said, ‚ÄúIf he could introduce Gore to everyone 1:1 they would have won‚Äú

Dave Thinks no one gets it
People aren‚Äôt voters, they are taxpayers, they are journalists, they are citizens, they go to war, they die.¬† Politicians put themselves first and look down at the people.¬† Don‚Äôt look at that way, join the conversation like Channel 9 does.

Closing Thoughts
The Internet does not sway people 20 minutes before voting.¬† The Dean campaign feels they won the Democratic Activist Group.¬†¬† They lost it at the end.¬† There is a digitial divide where a lot of Democratic / Liberals don‚Äôt have Internet access.

item.title: Have you thanked a soldier lately?
item.description:
Ideas can spread quickly across the blogosphere.¬† Today I‚Äôd like to go out on a limb and float a baloon. This is something that I‚Äôve wrestled a lot about whether or not to post.

Have you thanked a soldier lately?
I‚Äôm a Canadian and also proud to be in the United States. In fact I am currently working on naturalizing to become a United States citizen. I often travel and sometimes with Lenn. A few weeks back when Lenn and I were in the valley on a customer visit he lost me in the airport.¬†Later to find me stopped with my bags dropped, shaking the hands of a few American soldiers. Lenn joked ,‚ÄùJeff, you‚Äôre more American than me.‚Äù üôÇ

Many of our troops start and end their Iraq Tour via our civilian airports. They are hard to miss wearing the desert fatigues. So, whenever I see a soldier I try to go over and give a quick thank you and get out of their way.

Everyone in America is entitled to their beliefs and is free to voice their opinions of the war.¬† But, when you see a soldier in the airport can you please take a moment to say thank you?

Today, I walked by the airport bar and saw three military men dress head to toe in desert gear.¬† They were Pete, John and Tim who were 30 minutes away to shipping out to Iraq. I bought them a drink, exchanged email addresses and wished them the best. It was touching, I am so proud of these guys.

Unfortunately they told me that this never happens and often people look away when they are seen in the airports. üôÅ¬†Pete, promises to send me some photos once they get over which was a very kind offer, totally unnecessary, but very nice.

Living in the world of software it is easy to get wound up in the latest fire drill or priority 1 software ‚Äúemergency‚Äù.¬† I forget how good life is over here being safe and sound.¬†

So regardless of whether or not you agree or disagree with war, the next time you see a soldier could you shake there hand or buy them a beer? Or even better spread the idea?

Thank you (shields up)

item.title: How Channel 9 Uses RSS
item.description:
It has been a little over seven days since our team launched Channel 9. I‚Äôve had some instant message and email conversations with Customers and Microsoft employees on our use of RSS with Channel 9. I need to write some help on this for the site as I don‚Äôt think its clear as to how deep you can go with RSS on our site. I‚Äôll start first with this weblog entry and eventually I‚Äôll move this post into a help file for the site.

Currently there are three levels of RSS support on Channel 9:¬†Uber Level, Section Level¬†and Thread Level.¬†¬† All is RSS 2.0 and the last time I checked it validates with the RSS Validator.

**Uber Level
** Selecting the XML icon to the right of FAQ in our global navigation provides an RSS feed.¬† This one includes the top level threads for the entire Channel 9 site.¬†¬† If you want to follow everything this is the one you‚Äôll want to point your aggregator to.

_Image showing the XML icon for the Channel 9 uber RSS feed_

**Section Level
** If the Uber feed contains to much noise or if you want to break out your feeds by categories, then section level feeds might be more useful. The section feeds allow you to subscribe to just one section of Channel 9. An example would be if you only want to subscribe to the videos then use that section‚Äôs RSS feed.¬† It is located next to the title bar for that section (image below).¬†¬†

Our feeds do support RSS Enclosures as well so the videos should show up in your favorite aggregator.¬† If your aggregator does not support enclosures¬†we provide a link to the video as well.

_Image showing the XML icon for the Channel 9 section level RSS feed_

**Thread Level
** The final level of RSS Support is at the thread level. The idea behind this is instead of using email to track threads you are interested in we use RSS. You can subscribe/unsubscribe to a thread without using our system.

Its a pretty cool way of doing it and I use it all the time to keep tabs of what‚Äôs happening in my threads. To subscribe to a thread select the orange XML icon to the right of the thread subject.

_Image showing the XML icon for the Channel 9 thread level RSS feed_

**Continous improvement
** We‚Äôve made some tweaks to the feeds since launching, we added guid support¬†and¬†adjusted titles of the feeds.¬†¬† Unfortunately our enclosures just links to the streaming files, I‚Äôm working on getting it so that these link to the full download for the video.

We need to figure out the best way to link to the responses to a particular item.¬†¬† Some folks have suggested using the RSS Comments and others recommend Slashcomments.¬†¬† I‚Äôd really like some feedback on the best way to do this, what would you like to see.¬†¬† We are using a hybrid of forums and weblog software so¬†I am not sure if it is appropriate to use the RSS Comments tag for the follow up posts.

Watch Channel 9 on your TV
You might have noticed a custom RSS Module in our feeds, this is for Newsgator Media Center Edition.¬† Newsgator Media Center Edition uses RSS Enclosurers to bring Channel 9 to your television, its a pretty cool way to keep current on our site.

**Some things we want to add
** Soon we will add a watch list for you to track threads you find interesting on the site. With one click you can mark a thread as something you want to track.¬†You‚Äôll be able to get quick links to your threads from your Channel 9 profile. We‚Äôll also give you an RSS link too for these, I‚Äôd like to allow users to expose there watch list as an RSS link to other users to. We also need to turn on RSS Support for the Channel 9 Wiki.¬† FlexiWiki does not provide full content in its feed, so we need to add that in.

**OPML Support
** Once we fix other bugs and add features requested by our users¬†I hope that we can add an OPML listed of Channel 9 users that enables people to track the webloggers and feeds submitted by Channel 9 users. We‚Äôll need to add an RSS element to people profiles, but I think this could be pretty cool.

It has been a lot of fun working on Channel 9, thank you for visiting the site and giving us your feedback. We‚Äôre working hard to make it a fun place to be.

item.title: If its good enough for seven days I'll buy it
item.description:
Tonight Scoble mentioned, my seven day rule for evaluating software and I figured I‚Äôd explain a bit more about my short attention span for new applications.¬†

I love to try out new software all the time, in fact its sort of an obsession.¬† I‚Äôm always on the prowl for cool new applications.¬† After seven days of use though if I‚Äôm not totally blowon away or if its not improving my PC life, its straight to add/remove programs I go. (Please, have a good un-installer).¬†

I actually go as far as to set a reminder in Outlook for seven days from the installation date.¬† When that reminder goes off I either send the author a cheque for their great work (even if its a 30 day evaluation) or I remove the application from my system.¬†

Some of the applications which have made it past my seven day rule have included Newsgator, David Allen‚Äôs¬†Outlook Add-in, and ActiveWords.¬†¬† This week it is the Groove 3.0 Beta, which appears to be a winner.¬†¬†

If I‚Äôm not using the application regularly after seven days, I remove it from my system.¬†¬† It keeps my system clean (hopefully it is a good uninstaller) and I move onto the next new good thing.

**Why only seven days?
**
1.¬† Seven days is enough time to start/break a new habit.¬† I try make an effort to use the new software and make it part of my day.¬†¬†I do try and give the software an honest chance though, if it is a bad week with lots of un-ordinary activity (weird hours, travel) I‚Äôll evaluate the software on a later date.

2.¬† In seven days I‚Äôll use multiple machines, I‚Äôll be at home and work.¬†¬† Is the software important enough and more importantly useful that I‚Äôll use it across multiple machines?

**What will make a piece of software get registered vs. uninstalled?
**
1.¬† Does it play well with my other applications or does it clobber my other applications?

2.¬† Does it have a weird user interface or is the experience sleek?

3.¬† Is the data easily available to all of my machines or do I have to perform registry judo to get the data to another desktop?

4.¬†¬†Does it improve my PC experience, make me more productivity or do I have fun with it?

5.¬† Have I completely forgotten about the application after seven days?

That‚Äôs my seven day rule of taking new software for a spin.¬†¬†

What do you look for when you‚Äôre evaluating new software?

item.title: Moving from Radio to DasBlog
item.description:
With no disrespect intended for to Radio Userland I made the move to DasBlog this weekend from my old site.  I also secured a domain name giving this place a bit more permanance.   For those of you considering making such a move I’ve included some tips and utilities to help you on your way that will allow you to get DasBlog up and runng and make it so you can take your Radio content and comments aloing with you.  

 

Where can get the you get the latest version of Dasblog?<o:p></o:p>

The latest version of DasBlog is on the Dasblog GotDotNet Workspace, this is newer than the one on the Dasblog website.

<o:p>¬†</o:p>

Any installation issues?<o:p></o:p>

The beauty of DasBlog is that it is all file system based and no SQL server was needed.¬† Installation for me was as simple as dragging and dropping the project files to my web server and setting the correct permissions.¬†¬† I‚Äôm running Windows Server 2003 on Webhost4life.¬† In order to DasBlog up and running I had to give NETWORKSERVICE read and write permissions to the /content, /siteconfig and /logs directories.¬†¬† Thanks Omar<o:p></o:p>

<o:p>¬†</o:p>

What about your Radio content and comments, do you lose them?<o:p></o:p>

Yes, you can bring your previous Weblog entries and the associated comments along with you.¬† Here‚Äôs how you can do it:<o:p></o:p>

<o:p>¬†</o:p>

¬†¬†¬†¬†Importing the Content<o:p></o:p>

  1. Turn on XML Archiving of posts in Radio Userland.¬† On my machine I saved these to C:\Program Files\Radio UserLand\backups\weblogarchive)<o:p></o:p>
  2. The XML archiving does not happen until after midnight.¬† To force the archiving to happen immediaitely complete these steps:<o:p></o:p>

¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Open the Radio Client Application (Right click on the Radio Tray icon and selet open)<o:p></o:p>

¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Hit CTRL + ; to open the Quick Script window <o:p></o:p>

¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Type ‚Äúradio.weblog.archive.update()‚Äù <o:p></o:p>

¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Hit the Run button <o:p></o:p>

¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Watch the status messages on the ‚ÄúAbout Radio Window‚Äù. You‚Äôll see it write a message for each post it‚Äôs actively archiving. When it stops, your archive files should all be there.
<o:p></o:p>

  1. Download the DasBlog Radio Importer tool and run pointing it to where Radio Userland has stored the Archived XML from step 1.
    ¬†¬†
    DasBlogRadioImport.exe
    /from:‚ÄùC:\Program Files\Radio UserLand\backups\weblogarchive‚Äù
    /to:‚ÄùC:\DasBlogContent”
    <o:p>¬†</o:p>
  2. Once the import is completed, you can copy the c:\dasblogcontent\ files to the DasBlog \Content folder and you‚Äôll have all the entries on your site.

Thanks to Sam Gentile and Drew Marsh and Google J for your posts that helped me get through this. <o:p></o:p>

<o:p>¬†</o:p>

Importing the Comments
Scott Hanselman wrote a utility that will import your Radio Userland comments as well.¬† This cool tool is in the source project for DasBlog so you‚Äôll need to download the source and compile.¬† If you don‚Äôt want to do this, I‚Äôve compiled a version and placed a copy here.¬† The format for the tool is:

<o:p></o:p>

DasBlogRadioCommentImport.exe
/commentserver:http://radiocomments.userland.com
/userid:<######>
/contentdir:‚ÄùC:\DasBlogContent‚Äù <o:p></o:p>

<o:p>¬†</o:p>

Notes:<o:p></o:p>

¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Make sure you know what your comment server is.¬† Check your HTML, some folks use radiocomments2, etc<o:p></o:p>

¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Use your radio user id WITHOUT leading zeros.<o:p></o:p>

¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Make sure you use ‚Äú‚Äù quotes when giving the path to your /content directory<o:p></o:p>

¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† This app has ZERO error handling, so if Radio ever changes their comment HTML, good luck.<o:p></o:p>

¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Make sure you‚Äôve ran the RadioCommentImporter successfully first with the same user id, otherwise the Radio PostIds won‚Äôt ‚Äúline up‚Äù<o:p></o:p>

<o:p>¬†</o:p>

¬†¬†¬†¬† Copy the entire C:\DasBlogContent\ folder to the DasBlog /content folder.<o:p></o:p>

<o:p>¬†</o:p>

How can I save my permalinks?<o:p></o:p>

I‚Äôll be honest, I don‚Äôt have this working yet, but thought I‚Äôd put this in for completeness, let me know if you‚Äôre successful in getting this working. ¬†Essentially it‚Äôs a custom http handler to watch for referrers from your original Radio Weblog.¬†¬† Details are over on Scott‚Äôs Weblog, I‚Äôll try to get this working next weekend and will upd
ate this.<span sty

le=“mso-spacerun: yes”>¬† This assumes that you still have a site over at Userland Software.

¬†

That‚Äôs all, I‚Äôve got my old content and a shiny new home.¬†¬† Welcome to the show..

item.title: Is Dave headed in this direction?
item.description:
I think I know where Dave is headed with his new categorization system, or at least this is where¬†I hope he is headed. üôÇ

What if all Weblog entries had religous use of categories like Dave‚Äôs has been applying to his posts since inception?¬†¬†

First off its not realistic to think everyone will change their ways and become the masters of categories.¬†¬† Also what I think might be a story about home improvement to another person could be about modern art.¬†¬† To make this happen we need to involve the Weblog community to categorize the Weblog world.¬†

Here‚Äôs one way to do it:

Imagine if the aggregator author‚Äôs incorporated randomn peer privilege into their products like Slashdot.org¬†has.¬† But with one big difference.¬† Instead of giving people the ability to moderate a post up or down people, it could be used to apply categories to the posts.¬†¬†¬† This category data would be rolled back up to an impartial set of servers, distributed via P2P and back to the originating weblog.¬†¬†¬† This would give us an open directory for browsing weblogs.

I spend way too much time scouting Google for Weblog posts for topics that I am interested in.¬† A¬†distributed system like this with items tagged by the community in an open hierarchy would be really amazing.¬†¬†

This sort of reminds me of the good old days of the web when Yahoo was so awesome because it had humans building their index.

So is this what Dave is up to?

item.title: Pumpkin Pancakes aka tomorrow's non-Atkins breakfast
item.description:
2 1/3 cups Bisquick baking mix

  • 2 tablespoons dark brown sugar, firmly packed <o:p></o:p>

  • 1/4 teaspoon ground cinnamon <o:p></o:p>
  • 1/4 teaspoon ground nutmeg <o:p></o:p>
  • 1/4 teaspoon ground ginger <o:p></o:p>
  • 1 1/4 cups milk <o:p></o:p>
  • 2 eggs, lightly beaten <o:p></o:p>
  • 1/3 cup mashed pumpkin <o:p></o:p>
  • 1/4 cup vegetable oil <o:p></o:p>

Beat all ingredients with whisk or hand beater until well blended. Pour batter by scant 1/4 cupfuls onto hot, lightly greased griddle or skillet. Cook until tops are bubbly and edges are dry. Turn and cook pumpkin pancakes until golden brown.

Makes about 15 to 18 pumpkin pancakes

item.title: Time for some Rider Pride!
item.description:
My lazy boy recliner is ready, a mesquite flavoured beef roast is slow cooking on the grill and at 4:00 PM PST (Channel 99, CBC on Comcast in Seattle) the Saskatchewan Roughriders are playing the Edmonton Eskimos for the 2003 Western Conference Final.¬†

If you have spent anytime of your life living in the Canadian Province of Saskatchewan you would be hard pressed to not be a die hard Rider fan.¬† The Saskatchewan Roughriders are definitely¬†Canada‚Äôs most loved football team and of course have the best fans in the world.¬†¬†

The drive for the Grey Cup this year is extra special as it will be held in the Roughrider‚Äôs home town of Regina.¬†¬† If the Riders win today they will play for the cup in their home town.¬†¬† So emotions are running high for me today, its hard not to get teary eyed thinking about this sports team.¬†¬†

The Riders and of course their fans symbolize a way of life and a set of values from the Prairie province that I grew up in.¬†¬† Words like tenacity, never giving up, loyalty come to mind when I think of this team and the fans.¬†¬†I hope they win today, if so Grey Cup Party at my house next weekend.¬†

Let‚Äôs go Riders!¬†
Let‚Äôs go!

item.title: Thanks Giving with the Parents
item.description:
My parents were in town this week and in honour of their arrival we celebrated an early and also a belated Thanksgiving Dinner.  I missed Canadian Thanksgiving Dinner up at my parents house and will be away for the upcoming American one.  One of the advantages of being a Canadian married to an American is that we celebrate both the American and Canadian dates.  

The week has been great!   I’ve been getting caught up on sleep and of course my gaming.  I picked up both Tiger Woods Golf and the Grand Theft Auto Double Pack for my XBox.   Tiger Woods is awesome and I catch myself thinking that the planes flying overhead are in my neighborhood and coming from the Television set.  Golf on the XBox is so relaxing.  So after I few rounds of golf I fired up Grand Theft Auto.  I had to see what the fuss was all about it. I’ll be honest though although this game is fun there is no way this game is coming out when my four year old is awake.  I really like though how the guys at Rock Star seem to merge a movie/storyline into game play.   This is the future of entertainment!

I picked up a new truck last month and have been itching to begin tweaking with it.  The truck is a Chevrolet Silverado Extended Cab.   It is great for hauling bark up to suburbia, but it needs personality.  My plan is to drop it 2 inches front and rear and replace factory rims with some 20" customs.  Jessie James from West Coast Choppers fame has the wheels I want, but it will be sometime before I can justify these babies.   I am going to keep looking for something similar, but more reasonably priced. 

So this week I kept things within by budget by installing a Billet Grill from Carriage Works and also tinted the windows out.  I am really happy how the grill turned out, very nice lines.

I’ll keep researching on the wheels and if you see any good deals on wheels, let me know.  

Tomorrow is Dad daughter day as I am taking my little one off to Brother Bear.  Great comeback for the ultimate hosers.

item.title: It sure is good to be back home again
item.description:
PDC¬†is over and its great to be back home.¬†¬† Man, it feels just like yesterday that we were down in LA checking out the venue, visiting Universal and doing hotel¬†visits.¬†¬†

In addition to being one of those guys helping with some of the logistics for the event I was part of a team of people amping community around the PDC.¬†¬† This included the PDC 2003 Community Environment (yes, we know lousy name).¬†¬† The goal for this application was to give folks easy access to news, session resources and newsgroups and to do so in a sexy smart client application.¬†¬† We learnt a lot about Windows Forms in the process and hopefully gave you a useful tool.

One side effect of working on a PDC is you get to know a¬†lot of people¬†from around the company.¬† I still get a little star struck when I am around these folks, but seeing them up close and personal really was a thrill.¬†¬† Whenever I see people like this speak, I try and apply a bit of what they do to my talks.¬†¬† I am¬† a newbie at presenting so I respect¬†anyone who¬†can get up in front of¬†a large crowd like that and rock out like that.¬†¬†

I took a lot of photos during the event, many behind the scenes.¬†¬† Here‚Äôs one of Don and Chris a few hours before their Lap Around Longhorn keynote in the cafe of The Standard.

Back to reality.¬†¬† On the homefront, life is slowly returning to normal, it is weird taking time off, sleeping in and just generally being around.¬† Heck tomorrow I get to take my 4 year old to preschool.¬† What a change from the in work by 7:30 am and home by x:00 am.¬†¬†

My wife‚Äôs birthday present is slowly but surely taking shape.¬†¬† Here‚Äôs the latest update photo of Jodie in action.

Jodie will be back again tomorrow so I‚Äôll put up more pictures then detailing progress.¬† It is amazing to watch her paint.¬† The colours come out at first so bold then watching here soften them up and then enhance the details.¬†¬† I‚Äôve had to promise my wife not to do Bob Ross impersonations while Jodie paints.¬† üôÇ
